{{Refimprove|date=October 2014}} {{Infobox film | name = Thirteenth Child | image = 13th Child film poster.jpg | caption = Film poster | director = [[Thomas Ashley (producer)|Thomas Ashley]]
Steven Stockage | producer = | writer = Michael Maryk
[[Cliff Robertson]] | starring = [[Cliff Robertson]]
[[Lesley-Anne Down]]
[[Christopher Atkins]]
[[Robert Guillaume]] | cinematography = Howard Krupa | music = [[Peter Calandra]] | editing = | distributor = Unipix Entertainment | released = {{Film date|2002|10|25}} | budget = $5,000,000 | runtime = 99 minutes | country = United States | language = English }} '''''13th Child''''' (or '''''The 13th Child: Legend of the Jersey Devil''''') is a 2002 [[direct-to-video]] [[horror film]] directed by [[Thomas Ashley (producer)|Thomas Ashley]] and Steven Stockage. It is inspired by the [[Jersey Devil]]. The screenplay was written by Michael Maryk and [[Cliff Robertson]], who also stars in the film.{{Citation |last=Nash |first=Margo |title=The Devil You Think You Know |newspaper=The New York Times |pages=11 |date=October 13, 2002 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/10/13/nyregion/the-devil-you-think-you-know.html}} The story is based on ''The Jersey Devil'' by James F. McCloy and Ray Miller Jr.{{Citation |last=Rosen |first=Judith |title=Jersey Devil takes the screen |newspaper=Publishers Weekly |pages=22 |date=November 18, 2002 |url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/print/20021118/32197-jersey-devil-takes-the-screen.html}} The film was shot in New Jersey at [[Wharton State Forest]], [[Batsto Village]], and [[Hammonton, New Jersey|Hammonton]] in the [[Pine Barrens (New Jersey)|Pine Barrens]] of [[New Jersey]]. == Cast == * [[Cliff Robertson]] as Mr. Shroud * [[Lesley-Anne Down]] as District-Attorney Murphy * [[Christopher Atkins]] as Ron * [[Robert Guillaume]] as Riley * [[John Wesley (actor)|John Wesley]] as Jones * [[Peter Jason]] as Coroner == Reception == Critical reception for the film has been negative and the film holds a rating of 40% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 5 reviews.{{Cite web |title=13th Child |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/13th_child/ |website=Rotten Tomatoes |date=2002-01-01 |accessdate=2015-11-30}} David N. Butterworth heavily panned the film, as he felt that "Anyone who quickly denounced Madonna's "''[[Swept Away (2002 film)|Swept Away]]''" as being the worst film of 2002 clearly hadn't seen "''13th Child''."" Charles Tatum from ''eFilmCritic.com'' panned the film's script, and character development.{{cite web |last1=Tatum |first1=Charles |title=Movie Review – 13th Child – eFilmCritic |url=http://www.efilmcritic.com/review.php?movie=8565 |website=eFilmCritic.com |publisher=Charles Tatum |accessdate=17 October 2014}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0273041}} * {{AllMovie title|289519}} * [http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/13th_child_legend_of_the_jersey_devil/ 13th Child] at [[Rotten Tomatoes]] * [http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title.jsp?stid=535275&atid=0&category=overview 13th Child] at [[Turner Classic Movies]] [[Category:2002 films]] [[Category:2002 horror films]] [[Category:2000s monster movies]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Direct-to-video horror films]] [[Category:Jersey Devil in fiction]] [[Category:Films shot in New Jersey]] [[Category:Films set in New Jersey]] [[Category:American monster movies]] {{2000s-horror-film-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Advent VideoBeam''' is a big-screen [[television]] that was invented in the 1970s by [[Advent Corporation]], founded by [[Henry Kloss]]. Both picture and sound are projected from the television's [[projector]] base towards a curved screen, where they are reflected back towards the viewer. It is a [[plug-and-play]] system, which means it has few adjustments, to make it easier to install.<ref>{{cite web|last=Guttenberg|first=Steve|title=The Advent VideoBeam 1000 Projection System|url=http://www.soundandvision.com/content/advent-videobeam-1000-projection-system|work=SOUND&VISION|accessdate=November 26, 2013}}</ref> In 1978, its advertised sale price was $3,000. <ref>{{cite web|title=Magazine Ad For Advent VideoBeam Television 'Paid For Itself In Beer'|work=Playboy Magazine, 1978|url=http://magazinesadsandbooks.com/Magazine-Ad-For-Advent-VideoBeam-Television-TV-Paid-For-Itself-In-Beer-1978-P3086614.aspx}}</ref>
==Characteristics== * 7-foot screen (51.5" x 68.5") * 180 watts power consumption * Focal distance fixed at 100" <ref>{{cite web|title=Videobeam 1000|url=http://www.radiomuseum.org/r/adventcorp_videobeam_1000.html}}</ref> * Projection technology: [[Cathode ray tube]] with rear-facing 3" phosphor screen and [[collimator|collimating]] mirror * Good quality projection * Clear, well-defined, and bright * Easy to install<ref>{{cite web|title=WallVisions- Advent VideoBeam Brochure|url=http://www.walvisions.com/ArchivePages/walvisions__advent_videobeam_brochure.htm|work=WalVisions|accessdate=November 26, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Television technology]]

revision.text:
[[File:070502 005 00.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Here starts the Bermuda Triangle. It is the popular name of the quarter around Graf-Engelbert Monument where Bochum's legendary "scene" is located.]]
''Bermudadreieck'' or ''Bermuda3Eck'' (Bermuda Triangle) is the designation for an area in the center of [[Bochum]], Germany, with a high density of bars and restaurants, bounded by (clockwise from top) the streets Südring, Brüderstraße, Kortumstraße and Viktoriastraße. The number of gastronomic establishments has increased since the beginning of the 1980s, spurred by the short distance to the [[Schauspielhaus Bochum|Bochum Theater]], [[Union Theater]] and the main train station. It is served by Engelbert-Brunnen/Bermudadreieck [[Trams in Bochum/Gelsenkirchen|U-Straßenbahn]] Station, on lines 308 & 318.
== Culture and cuisine == There are over 60 catering establishments in the Bermuda Triangle. The area has expanded to approximately 2 km² with seating for over 8,000, including 4,200 seats outdoors. Over 3 million visitors are served per year. On sunny, summer weekends, there are often up to 30,000 visitors a day, including tourists from all across Germany. During major events, such as [[Bochum Total]], numbers can reach up to 300,000 a day.<ref name="Atlantic">Günter Ermlich. [http://www.atlantic-times.com/archive_detail.php?recordID=1543 "The Flower of the Coalfield"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716023332/http://www.atlantic-times.com/archive_detail.php?recordID=1543 |date=July 16, 2011 }} ''The Atlantic Times,'' A monthly newspaper from Germany. November 2008. Accessed March 2, 2010</ref> The Bermuda Triangle provides about 1,600 jobs. The development of the area has privatized once-public space and turned it into beer gardens, which, although not without controversy, has been accepted by the general population.{{citation needed|date=March 2010}}
Bermuda Triangle property rates have risen so much in recent years, that longtime retailers are increasingly forced out. The vacant spaces are then taken over by the restaurant and catering sector. Triangle prices for food and beverages are often above the local average, sometimes comparing with expensive cities like [[Düsseldorf]], [[Munich]] and [[Hamburg]].
The heart of the Bermuda Triangle is the square around the now removed Engelbert Fountain, named after Count [[Engelbert III of the Mark]]. There is a procession each year, named the ''Maiabendfest'' (May Evening Festival). The fountain was removed in spring 2009.
Among the major events are: * the multi-day "Bochum Total," the biggest music festival in Europe * "Stühle raus ", the annual symbolic opening of the open air season. * the ''Maiabendfest'' (May Evening Fest), a local festival steeped in tradition and legend, featuring a long procession.
The Bermuda Triangle is a cultural focal point of Bochum and a popular meeting place for people from throughout the Ruhr region. In addition to these events, it is near the [[Schauspielhaus Bochum]], a nightclub, several cinemas and the construction site of a new concert hall for the [[Bochum Symphony Orchestra]] to be erected nearby.<ref name="Atlantic" />
== History == With a multitude of diverse catering outlets, [[:de:Logos Gruppe|Logos Gruppe]] counts among the main developers of the Bermuda3Eck since the 1980s. In the mid 90s they covered almost the whole market in the Bermuda3Eck with a broad spectrum of diverse catering concepts. Logos Gruppe were initiators of ISG Bermuda3Eck e.V., one of the first [[Business improvement district|Business Improvement Districts]] of [[North Rhine-Westphalia]], with Logos [[Chief_Executive_Officer|CEO]] Hans-Joachim Hauschulz a member of its [[supervisory board]].
==See also== * [[List of restaurant districts and streets]]
== References == <references/>
== External links == {{commons}} * [http://www.bochum.de/C125708500379A31/vwContentByKey/N26GLCB7862BBOSEN Information on Bochum] (with map) * [http://bochumtotal.de/index.php?module_id=6&location_id=19&company_id=0&button_id=1632&cmd=doAction&module_page=p Bochum Total] Official website * [http://www.bermuda3eck.de Bermudadreieck] Official website {{Language icon|de}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110420075128/http://www.ruhr-szene.de/tag/Bermudadreieck list of all gastronomic establishments] {{Language icon|de}}
[[Category:Bochum|Bermuda3eck]] [[Category:Entertainment districts in Germany]] [[Category:Restaurant districts and streets in Germany]]

{{Distinguish|Jigsaw (Saw character){{!}}Jigsaw}} {{EngvarB|date=April 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{refimprove|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox character | series = [[Saw (franchise)|Saw]] | color = #B60000 | name = Billy the Puppet | image = Saw billy.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | first = {{Plainlist| * '''Film''': * ''[[Saw (2003 film)|Saw 0.5]]'' (2003) * '''Video game''': * [[Saw: The Video Game]] (2009) }} | last = {{Plainlist| * '''Film''': * ''[[Jigsaw (2017 film)|Jigsaw]]'' (2017) * '''Video game''': * [[Dead by Daylight]] (2017) }} | creator = [[James Wan]] | voice = [[Tobin Bell]] | nickname = Billy the Puppet | gender = Male | species = Puppet | lbl21 = Relationships | data21 = {{ubl|[[Jigsaw (Saw character)|John Kramer/Jigsaw]]
(deceased creator and voice)|[[Mark Hoffman]]
(deceased later voice)}} | lbl22 = [[Modus operandi|M.O.]] | data22 = Delivering messages to subjects of Jigsaw via television screen or in person. }} '''Billy''' is a [[puppet]] that has appeared in the [[Saw (franchise)|''Saw'' franchise]]. It was used by [[Jigsaw (Saw character)|John Kramer]] to communicate with his test subjects by delivering recorded messages, often appearing on a television screen or occasionally in person to describe the details of the traps and the means by which the test subjects could survive. In the film series, before becoming the Jigsaw Killer, Kramer was believed to have created Billy to be given as a toy to his unborn child. However, Jill, his wife, is shown to miscarry after being hit in the stomach by a swinging hospital door due to Cecil ramming it open without looking. Kramer's unresolved anger was likely a primary motive for creating the puppet as a vehicle for his instructions trap victims. The traps he created can be seen as a manifestation of his anger with people who he feels don't appreciate having their life when his unborn baby was killed before having a life of its own. Although it has never actually been identified in the films, "Billy" is the name by which it is referred to by writers, directors, and members of the cast and crew on documentaries and interviews. The name was given to it by its real-life creator [[James Wan]], who is the director and co-writer of ''Saw''. Some claim that the name is spelled "Billie", though Wan himself spells it "Billy".Saw: Uncut special features The endurance and popularity of the ''Saw'' franchise has resulted in the production of Billy merchandise, as well as references in other media. Billy has become a type of [[mascot]] for the ''Saw'' series. ==Characteristics== Billy appears to be a male [[ventriloquism#Ventriloquist's dummy|ventriloquist's dummy]], as its jaw is movable to give the suggestion that it is talking; however, it is not used in the same manner, as the entire doll is frequently seen moving on its own. Its face is white, with a protruding brow and cheeks that have red spirals painted on them. His red lips form a grin. His eyes are black with red irises, and his head is topped with black, messy hair. Billy is always depicted wearing a black [[tuxedo]], with a white shirt and gloves, red bow tie, and red handkerchief in the breast pocket. He also has red [[Mary Jane (shoe)|Mary Janes]] for shoes. In the short film, he is seen wearing a green [[bowler hat]]. He is often riding an old-fashioned red [[tricycle]]. The only sound originating directly from him is a generic electronic cackle much like one would find in a [[Halloween]]-type toy. ==Construction== According to Wan, the construction of the original puppet's face for ''[[Saw (2003 film)|Saw]]'' involved [[clay]], [[papier-mâché]], and black [[Table tennis|ping pong]] balls with the irises painted in for the eyes. Paper towel rolls were used internally.Saw DVD special features To make him move, the puppeteers pulled him along on a fishing line. For ''[[Saw II]]'', Billy was redesigned with mechanical features that could be manipulated by a remote control, including his unhinged jaw and his eyes.{{cite web|url=http://www.joblo.com/horror-movies/news/saw-2-diary-2|title=Saw 2: Dairy #2|last=Hoffman|first=Gregg|authorlink=Gregg Hoffman|publisher=[[JoBlo.com]]|page=2|date=13 May 2005|accessdate=24 August 2011}} For ''[[Saw III]]'', the prop crew was given the original puppet, but found it unfit for work, as time had damaged it. Instead, they recreated Billy, using waterjet-cut foam for his body instead of fiberglass, equipped with plates to hold the puppet together and magnets to attach him to his tricycle. The back of his head was removable, to make it easier to slide animatronic pieces in.{{cite video|title=The Details of Death: The Props of Saw III|medium=DVD|publisher=[[Lionsgate Home Entertainment]]|people=Jason Ehl (props builder)|date=2007 |time=0:32–1:41}} For ''[[Saw IV]]'', the prop crew again made the body of waterjet-cut foam, held together by metal rods. They used strong magnets to make a flat rear for the puppet, so it could be easily positioned on any metal surface. The resin-filled ping-pong ball eyes were moved with a remote control, as was the mouth. {{Clear}} ==Appearances in films== ===''Saw''=== {{Main|Saw (2004 film)}} In the first ''[[Saw (2004 film)|Saw]]'' movie, Billy is seen on a television set by [[Amanda Young]], telling her about the reverse bear trap that was hooked into her [[jaw]]s, and explaining that the key to remove it is in the stomach of her "dead cellmate" (who is actually a heavily sedated man) lying in the room. After she disembowels the man and frees herself, Billy comes into the room on his tricycle to congratulate her. Later, [[List of Saw characters#Adam Faulkner|Adam]] remembers seeing the puppet in his apartment when the lights went out. As he was searching through the [[Darkroom|dark rooms]] using his camera flash, the puppet's eerie laugh rang through the apartment, and Adam hit it with a [[Baseball bat|bat]] until it stopped. When Detectives [[David Tapp]] and [[List of Saw characters#Steven Sing|Steven Sing]] uncover Jigsaw's latest hideout, they snoop around the area and pull the blankets off several covered items, one of which proves to be Billy. ===''Saw II''=== {{Main|Saw II}} In ''[[Saw II]]'', Billy is seen on the screen at the beginning of the film, giving [[List of Saw characters#Michael Marks|Michael]] hints about the death mask he is wearing. It plays out similarly to Amanda's test, except Michael dies. Later, when the detectives discover Jigsaw's new hideout, several officers walk up a caged [[Stairs|staircase]] and are greeted by Billy, who wheels into sight at the top of the stairs on his tricycle and laughs. The cage then becomes electrified after one officer steps on a rigged stair that breaks his legs.{{Clear}} ===''Saw III''=== {{Main|Saw III}} In ''[[Saw III]]'', Jigsaw is seen constructing Billy in a [[flashback (narrative)|flashback]] for the purpose of Amanda's game, painting the puppet's face. Later, Billy appears on videotape to inform both [[List of Saw characters#Troy|Troy]] and [[List of Saw characters#Allison Kerry|Kerry]] of their respective traps. The puppet is also seen in the background of a flashback that features Jigsaw and Amanda discussing her loyalty. He is also used to remind [[List of Saw characters#Jeff Denlon|Jeff Denlon]] of his dead son at one point, by being laid down next to his [[tricycle]] in the same position Jeff's son was in when he was killed. The puppet gives a mocking laugh until Jeff beats it into silence. After Jeff cuts Jigsaw's throat, a reflection of Billy can be seen on Jigsaw's heart rate monitor for a split second. {{Clear}} ===''Saw IV''=== {{Main|Saw IV}} Billy is first seen in ''[[Saw IV]]'' when [[List of Saw characters#Rigg|Rigg]] awakes after being attacked in his apartment and rendered [[unconsciousness|unconscious]]. Rigg opens his bathroom door, pulling a trigger-wire from a TV set. Billy appears on the screen to explain Rigg's game. Upon leaving the room, Rigg is greeted by another message concerning his first test, referring to [[List of Saw characters#Brenda|a woman]] Jigsaw deemed to be a criminal that had been placed in a machine that would scalp her. Agents [[List of Saw characters#Peter Strahm|Peter Strahm]] and [[List of Saw characters#Lindsey Perez|Lindsey Perez]] later find Billy in a room in a school, sitting on a chair surrounded by [[candle]]s. From a microcassette recorder hung around the puppet's neck, Perez learns that her partner will soon take the life of an innocent man (who is later revealed to be [[List of Saw characters#Jeff Denlon|Jeff Denlon]]), and that her next move is critical. Billy's eyes begin turning to Perez while a low voice on the tape murmurs, "Open the door." Perez leans in to hear this last, at which point Billy's face explodes, blowing [[Fragmentation (weaponry)|shrapnel]] into her face and neck. Perez collapses into Strahm's arms as Billy begins to laugh. There is also a flashback of Jigsaw giving a less menacing, early version of Billy to [[List of Saw characters#Jill Tuck|Jill Tuck]] as a gift for their unborn son Gideon. An interview with [[Tobin Bell]] revealed that this was the beginning of a storyline concerning the origins of Billy, as well as his tricycle, to be explored in future ''Saw'' films.{{cite web |author=Topel, Fred|title=Tobin Bell Previews Saw V Surprises |url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/saw_4/news/1686930/tobin_bell_previews_saw_v_surprises |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher= |date=30 November 2007 |accessdate=24 November 2009}} ===''Saw V''=== {{Main|Saw V}} Billy appeared in the opening sequence of ''[[Saw V]]'', to tell [[List of Saw characters#Seth Baxter|Seth Baxter]] the rules of his game, which is later revealed to have been set up by [[Mark Hoffman]] to frame Jigsaw and kill Seth. It is unknown how Hoffman created the tape for this game. According to a list of potential Jigsaw victims, Seth was the third person tested after Cecil and Mark. In those tests, Jigsaw didn't use a puppet. Billy is also seen at the beginning of all of the team's traps. The early version of Billy from a ''Saw IV'' flashback is seen in the background of a flashback explaining the connection between Jigsaw and Hoffman. ===''Saw VI''=== {{Main|Saw VI}} In ''[[Saw VI]]'', Billy appears on tape in the opening trap, which pits [[List of Saw characters#Simone|Simone]] and [[List of Saw characters#Eddie|Eddie]] against each other. He also addresses [[List of Saw characters#William Easton|William Easton]] during two of his four tests (Jigsaw himself addresses William via video in his first test). He appears "in person" in William's second test by way of hanging from a noose, and on video in the fourth. ''Saw VI'' marks the first time Billy was purposefully shown in person to deliver test information to victims. Snippets of the Seth Baxter tape which Billy is featured in are also played. ===''Saw 3D''=== {{Main|Saw 3D}} Billy appears in ''[[Saw 3D]]''. He gives [[List of Saw characters#Brad, Dina, and Ryan|Brad and Ryan]] instructions to their trap in person, does the same for Bobby Dagen's second test, and appears on tape for the others. When Hoffman goes to his hideout after he escapes the Reverse Beartrap, multiple Billy heads can be seen. His final appearance is in Hoffman's secret hideout at the end of the film; Hoffman blows it up, destroying Billy in the explosion. Billy's voice is changed, as if Jigsaw is using a voice changer, implying that it was Hoffman who recorded the tapes. ===''Jigsaw'' === {{Main|Jigsaw (2017 film)|}} Billy returns for the eighth Saw film titled "Jigsaw". He was first shown in the official trailer on his iconic tricycle. He is shown this time with illuminated eyes and shoes. In the film, he only appears twice. He appears once on his tricycle with a letter around his neck with the word "Confess" written on it. The second time is on tape with his eyes lit up for the grain silo trap. == Non-canon film appearances == ===''Saw 0.5''=== {{Main|Saw (2003 film)}} In the Original Saw short film, Billy is seen on a television set by David, telling him about the reverse bear trap that was hooked into his [[jaw]]s, and explaining that the key to remove it is in the stomach of his "dead cellmate" (who is actually a heavily sedated man) lying in the room. After he disembowels the man and frees himself, Billy comes into the room on his tricycle to congratulate him. ===''Dead Silence''=== {{Main|Dead Silence}} In the 2007 film ''[[Dead Silence]]'', one of the puppets, who appears on the film's poster and wears the same outfit as Jigsaw's puppet, is named Billy. The ''Saw'' puppet is also seen in the movie for a brief second, in a shot that reveals all of Mary Shaw's puppets in the attic above the theatre. ===''Death Sentence''=== {{Main|Death Sentence (2007 film)}} A [[graffiti]]-style painting of Billy's face can be seen on a wall in James Wan's film [[Death Sentence (2007 film)|''Death Sentence'']]. ===''Insidious''=== {{Main|Insidious (film)}} In the 2011 film ''[[Insidious (film)|Insidious]]'' there is a scene in which Josh (the father) is working late in the classroom and Billy is drawn in chalk on the blackboard behind his head. Underneath the drawing the number eight is shown, hinting at Jigsaw. ===''Scary Movie 4''=== {{Main|Scary Movie 4}} Billy the Puppet makes a cameo appearance as the parody antagonist. ===''Upgrade''=== {{Main|Upgrade (film)}} A [[graffiti]]-style painting of Billy's face can be seen on a wall in [[Leigh Whannell]]'s film [[Upgrade (film)|''Upgrade'']]. ==Other media== {{See also|List of Saw media|l1=Saw in other media}} ===Comic=== Billy can be seen in the corners of two panels near the beginning of ''[[List of Saw media#Saw: Rebirth|Saw: Rebirth]]'', foreshadowing John's eventual transformation into Jigsaw. The comic also appears to mark Billy as one of John's creations at the toy factory where he worked, but this backstory was negated in ''Saw IV''. ===Video games=== Billy, voiced by Tobin Bell, appears throughout [[Saw (video game)|''Saw: The Video Game'']] delivering hints and objectives to the player. He also featured prominently in marketing for the game. In the Freedom ending, Billy's reflection is seen on a T.V. when [[David Tapp|Tapp]] commits suicide. He returns in ''[[Saw II: Flesh & Blood]]'', the sequel to the first game, also voiced by Tobin Bell. Billy repeats his role as in the first game, giving hints and clues to the player. The player can also collect small Billy dolls throughout the game, which require solving more complicated puzzles to obtain them; they are off of the main path, so the player does not have to get them. ''Flesh & Blood'' is also the only time in the ''Saw'' franchise that he is actually called "Billy." Dead By Daylight: Chapter VII the SAW chapter. Billy is in the video game 'Dead by Daylight' as a NPC as part of the SAW chapter DLC. He appears when the player chooses 'the Pig' a licenced character from Saw. He is also seen in the map 'The Game, gideon's meatplant,' ===Amusement park appearances=== '''Saw [[Saw – The Ride|–]] The Ride''' {{Main|Saw – The Ride}} Billy appears on numerous screens throughout the queue line of [[Saw – The Ride]] at [[Thorpe Park]], England telling riders that they are not worthy of the life they have been given, implicating the ride to be one of Jigsaw's traps. He also appears on his tricycle at the start of the ride itself, riders on the second dispatched car (two cars are dispatched one after the other), the vehicle will stop while Billy gives a speech, informing you that there is no escape, and proclaiming, "Here's what happens when you lose", before allowing the train to pass – this regulates the distance between cars. He can also be seen before the car travels up the lift hill, appearing on a screen and saying "GAME OVER", and at the end of the ride, where his head can be seen on a shelf covered with body parts. '''Saw - The Maze''' The Saw Alive maze, also in Thorpe Park, allows parkgoers to be photographed with Billy. '''Saw: Game Over''' In the U.S., Billy appears several times in the maze Saw: Game Over at [[Halloween Horror Nights|Orlando Horror Nights]] at Universal Studios Florida. ==In popular culture== * A line of replica "Billy" dolls has been released for consumer purchase, mainly through gift stores. It retains the main characteristics of the doll, though is much cleaner in appearance. Billy Halloween masks and [[costume]]s have also been released for purchase. * In the "[[Koi Pond (The Office)|Koi Pond]]" episode of ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)|The Office]]'', [[Dwight Schrute]] dressed up as Billy for Halloween. * On a [[webisode]] of ''The Hardy Show'', [[Matt Hardy]] dressed up as Billy for Halloween. * In the [[The Cleveland Show (season 4)|Halloween]] episode of ''The Cleveland Show'', [[List of The Cleveland Show characters#Montclair Tubbs|Rallo]] dresses up as Billy and introduces the episode. * Before the releases of ''Saw III'' and ''Saw IV'', Billy was used in videos to promote the films on YouTube and MySpace. * Billy (with his name changed to ''Billy the Jigsaw Puppet'' for parody) is the main [[antagonist]] in ''[[Scary Movie 4]]''. * In the Internet series ''[[The Annoying Orange]]'', Billy appears in "Annoying Saw" and "Annoying Saw 2: The Annoying Death Trap", both in which Orange refers to him as "[[Joker (comics)|Clownface]]", "[[Emo]] [[Clown]]", and "[[Donald Trump]]". * Billy appears in a Dutch parody of ''The Little House on the Prairie'' from "De TV kantine". Nellie needs to cut off her arm or else she will see a man naked again which is seen earlier in the episode. * A parody of Billy, called Jigzaw, appears in episodes 148–149 of the anime ''[[Gin Tama]]''. In appearance he looks similar to Billy, with a white and red mask and is also dressed in a black tuxedo. He sports many of Billy's quailities, like appearing on a TV screen, trapping two characters in a familiar "game" and pitting them against each other. * In the ''[[Aqua Teen Hunger Force]]'' episode "The Marines", [[Frylock]] is captured by a puppet parodying Billy who demands him to shove a [[grapefruit spoon]] in his eye. * Singer [[Nicki Minaj]] used a Billy mask as the face of "Nemesis" during her setlist during [[Britney Spears]] [[Femme Fatale Tour]] in 2011. * In the internet videogame series ''Inkagames'', appear a character based on Billy called "Pigsaw", who is a recurring villain from the games. * Rapper [[Hopsin]]'s album [[Raw (Hopsin album)|Raw]] depicts Hopsin on a tricycle with his face painted to look like Billy. The album's title itself can be interpreted as a [[Saw (2004 film)|spoof of the film's title]]. * Experimental pop artist [[Eric Millikin]] created a large mosaic portrait of Billy out of Halloween candy and spiders as part of his "Totally Sweet" series in 2013.{{cite web|url = http://www.fearnet.com/news/news-article/get-taste-eric-millikins-totally-sweet-candy-monster-mosaics|title = Get a Taste of Eric Millikin's Totally Sweet Candy Monster Mosaics|last = Burkart |first = Gregory |publisher = [[FEARnet]]|accessdate = 9 November 2013}}{{cite web|url = http://www.freep.com/article/20131023/BLOG44/131011015/Eric-Millikin|title = Eric Millikin's totally sweet Halloween candy monster portraits|last = Millikin |first = Eric |publisher = [[Detroit Free Press]]|accessdate = 9 November 2013}} * In the ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' episode "[[The Hurt Locker, Part Two]]", [[Sue Sylvester]] uses a puppet resembling herself and Billy to communicate with characters she has kidnapped, [[Kurt Hummel|Kurt]] and [[Blaine Anderson|Blaine]]. * In the webcomic ''[[Homestuck]]'', Billy appears as one of the many puppets in Dave Strider's apartment. The character Caliborn also shares similarities with Billy. * In [[The Fairly OddParents]], Vicky dresses up as Billy the puppet to torture Timmy and Chloe. * In [[The Simpsons]] Bart takes his adopted brother to see a horror movie with Billy the Puppet on screen stabbing someone with a Chef Knife. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Saw franchise|Billy the Puppet}} * [[Dwight Schrute]] (portrayed by [[Rainn Wilson]]) [https://web.archive.org/web/20100117113218/http://www.zap2it.com/news/custom/photogallery/tv/zap-halloween-costumes-tv-characters-pictures%2C0%2C5892656.photogallery?index=18 dressed as Billy] * Example of [http://images.halloweencostumes.net/saw-jigsaw-mask.jpg ''Billy'' Halloween mask] {{Saw}} [[Category:Saw characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2003]] [[Category:Horror film characters]] [[Category:Fictional puppets]] [[Category:Mascots]]

There have been two '''[[Channel 4]] Banned seasons'''. The first aired in April 1991 over three weeks and saw the broadcast of a number of films and documentaries which had previously been banned from British television or cinema. The second was in 2004/2005 and consisted of a series of documentaries concerning the history of explicit and controversial material on British television.
==1991 Banned season==
''Banned'' was a series of programmes shown over a three-week period in April 1991.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.channel4.com/learning/microsites/W/wtc4/history/c4timeline.jsp|title= Channel 4 timeline|publisher= Channel 4|accessdate= 30 April 2009}}</ref> The idea for the season was conceived as a statement about the censorship of broadcasting at the time. The season included network television showings of ''[[Scum (film)|Scum]]'' (which was edited to remove some of the violent gang rape scene and the subsequent graphic suicide of the victim), ''[[Monty Python's Life of Brian]]'' (which was preceded by a warning that viewers may find the film's treatment of religious themes upsetting), the controversial documentary feature ''[[The Animals Film]]'' and [[Derek Jarman]]'s ''[[Sebastiane]]'' and ''[[Jubilee (1977 film)|Jubilee]]''. There was also a second broadcast of the controversial 1988 [[Thames Television]] documentary ''[[Death on the Rock]]'' which investigated [[Operation Flavius|the shooting]] of three members of the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army|IRA]] by the [[Special Air Service|SAS]] in [[Gibraltar]]. The season proved to be controversial and Channel 4 was investigated by the [[Obscene Publications Squad]] and referred to the [[Director of Public Prosecutions]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.offthetelly.co.uk/features/c4/1991.htm |title=Channel 4 At 25: 1991 compiled by Steve Williams, Ian Jones and Jack Kibble-White |accessdate=30 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080918234351/http://www.offthetelly.co.uk/features/c4/1991.htm |archivedate=September 18, 2008 }}</ref>
==2004/2005 Banned season==
The '''Channel 4 Banned season''' was a series of [[television]] [[documentary film|documentaries]] on the [[UK]]'s [[Channel 4]] in [[2004 in television|2004]]-[[2005 in television|2005]], examining the history of explicit and controversial material on British television, and its infiltration of the [[mainstream]].
These documentaries included (original airdate if known): *''[[X-Rated: The Pop Videos They Tried to Ban]]'', 24 July 2004 — [[Music video]]s ([https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0420327/ IMDb page]) *''[[X-Rated (2004 Channel 4 documentary)|X-Rated]]'', 9 December 2004 (possibly a.k.a. ''[[X-Rated: The Sex Films They Tried to Ban]]''<ref>[http://www.channel4.com/film/newsfeatures/microsites/B/banned/listings.html "Banned" official webpage], retrieved 30 March 2007</ref>) — About films given the [[X certificate]] by the [[BBFC]]. ([https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0447554/ IMDb]) *''[[X-Rated: The TV They Tried to Ban]]'', 6 March 2005 — A history of television programmes that caused controversy, pushed boundaries or were banned in some way. ([https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1564977/ IMDb]) *''[[X-Rated: Top 20 Most Controversial TV Moments]]'', March 2005 — Similar to the above, but measuring the number of complaints that programmes received ([https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0871022/ IMDb]) *''[[Banned in the UK]]'', 7, 8, 9, 10 March 2005 — Four-part series demonstrating different kinds of [[censorship]], such as censorship by the [[British government|government]] or of [[art]]. ([https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0840064/ IMDb]) *''[[X-Rated: The Ads They Couldn't Show]]'' — [[Television advertisement|TV advertisements]] that were controversial, or banned from UK broadcast due to their content. ([https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2254239/ IMDb])
