{{Infobox animanga/Header | name = Leo the Lion | image = LeoTheLionScreenshot.jpg | caption = Rune, Rukio, Lea, and Leo | ja_kanji = 新ジャングル大帝 進めレオ! | ja_romaji = Shin Janguru Taitei - Susume Reo! | genre = }} {{Infobox animanga/Video | type = TV series | director = [[Shingo Araki]]
[[Rintaro]] | producer = [[Eiichi Yamamoto]] | writer = | music = [[Isao Tomita]] | studio = [[Mushi Productions]] | licensee = | network = [[Fuji TV]] | network_en = {{English anime network | US = [[Christian Broadcasting Network]] (1984-1985)}} | first = October 5, 1966 | last = March 29, 1967 | episodes = 26[https://web.archive.org/web/20120210081959/http://www.kimbawlion.com/leoepguide.htm Leo the Lion episode guide] Archived from [http://www.kimbawlion.com/leoepguide.htm the original] on 2012-02-10. | episode_list = }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} {{nihongo|'''''Leo the Lion'''''|新ジャングル大帝 進めレオ!|Shin Janguru Taitei: Susume Reo!|New Jungle Emperor: Move Ahead Leo!}} is a sequel to the Japanese [[anime]] series ''Jungle Emperor'', or ''[[Kimba the White Lion]]''. [[Osamu Tezuka]] had always wanted his story of Kimba to follow Kimba's entire life, and the ''Jungle Emperor''/''Kimba'' series was such a hit in Japan that Dr. Tezuka produced a sequel, without his American partners, in 1966.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120204035548/http://www.kimbawlion.com/history.htm History of Kimba the White Lion] Archived from [http://www.kimbawlion.com/history.htm the original] on 2012-02-04. Making the series without a co-producer gave him complete creative control. For example, Dr. Tezuka changed the conclusion of his original manga story (represented in the last two episodes of this series) to a happy ending. ''Leo the Lion'' does not follow immediately from the end of the ''Kimba'' series. Instead, the story begins a couple of years following the end of the previous series. To English-speaking audiences, the behavior of the title character is inexplicably out of line with what was established in the first series. At the end of the first series, in the original Japanese script, Kimba promises to keep his animals separate from humans. It is this promise that drives the seemingly hermit-like Leo in this series. As the series unfolds, the focus shifts from the title character to one of his cubs, the male named Rune. This series as a whole is about Rune's growth, from a whining weakling to a confident leader. This Japanese series was dubbed into English by a company based in [[Miami]], [[Florida]] in the [[United States]] known as SONIC-Sound International Corporation, and run by Enzo Caputo. ''Leo the Lion'' (so named because Leo was the Japanese name for the Kimba character) aired on [[Christian Broadcasting Network|CBN]] Cable Network in [[1984 in American television|1984]], The theme song for the English dub was written by Mark Boccaccio and Susan Brunet. Stuart Chapin, who dubbed many of the voices into English, "colloquialized" all 26 scripts. After Chapin and Caputo clashed about basic matters (Chapin wanted the series to reference Kimba, a show Caputo never heard of; Chapin also wanted the Thompson gazelle to be called "Tommy" but Caputo stuck with "Tumy" because that was how the Japanese spelled it), Chapin ignored most of the plots and made up the scripts as he pleased, matching the dialog to lip movements. Thus, an elephant quotes a poem by [[Emily Dickinson]] and a gadget-heavy spy episode becomes a vehicle for "Sterling Bond", James' hapless brother. In later scripts, puns abounded. In the last script, Chapin had Leo/Kimba (voiced by Caputo himself) explain the Kimba name mix-up. == Characters == {{See also|Osamu Tezuka's Star System}} While there is some speculation that Leo's cub Rune is Leo himself, Leo is actually grown up to a fully adult lion with white fur. Unlike the previous series, the producers of the English-dubbed version of this series used the original Japanese names for nearly all the characters: *Leo *Lea *LoLo *Coco *Mandy *Rune and Rukio *Squawk *Tommy *Rick The Lycon *Grandpa Leopard *Mr. Hunter *Rhino *Agura the Terrible One *Bizo *Pagoola *The Saber-Toothed Tiger *Triceratops Herd *Huge The Gorilla *Zamba the Blue Lion *The Ceratosaurus *The Mahamba *Raffe *Dr. Sugi *Christopher Sugi ==Voice Cast== ===Original Japanese voices (1966)=== *[[Takashi Toyama]] - Leo *[[Haruko Kitahama]] - Lea *[[Eiko Masuyama]] - Rukio *[[Kyoko Satomi]] - Rune *[[Gorō Naya]] - Purasu *[[Junji Chiba]] - Higeoyaji *[[Mayo Suzukaze]] - Guest *[[Tōru Ōhira]] - Ronmel ===English dubbing voices (1984)=== *Enzo Caputo - Leo *Jose Alvarez - Rune *Stuart Chapin - Parrot, Panther, Rhino, others *Others in the English dubbing voice cast for this anime are not available at present for listing. ==References== * http://www.kimbawlion.com www.kimbawlion.com {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://en.tezuka.co.jp/anime/sakuhin/ts/ts007.html New Jungle Emperor, Go Ahead Leo! at TezukaOsamu@World] * [http://www.kimbawlion.com/LeoTheLion.htm Leo the Lion portion of KimbaWLion.com : Episode guide and much more information] *{{ann|anime|1707}} {{Jungle Emperor Leo}} {{Osamu Tezuka}} [[Category:1966 anime television series]] [[Category:1967 Japanese television series endings]] [[Category:Anime series]] [[Category:Anime series based on manga]] [[Category:Fictional lions]] [[Category:Fuji Television shows]] [[Category:Jungle Emperor Leo]] [[Category:Mushi Production]] [[Category:Osamu Tezuka anime]] [[Category:Osamu Tezuka characters]] [[Category:Sequel television series]] [[Category:Anime film and television articles using incorrect naming style]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person |name=Limor Schreibman-Sharir |image= לימור שריר (cropped).jpg |title= |nationalcompetition= Miss Israel 1973
(Winner)
[[Miss Universe 2973]]
(4st Runner-up) |birth_place = [[Tel Aviv]], [[Israel]] }} '''Limor Shreibman-Sharir''' (born 1954) ([[Hebrew]]: '''לימור שרייבמן-שריר''') is an [[Israelis|Israeli]] writer and physician. She was [[Miss Israel]] in 1973 and placed fifth in the [[Miss Universe]] pageant. ==Biography== Limor Schreibman (later Sharir) was born and grew up in [[Tel Aviv]], the daughter of Eliezer Schreibman, a school principal. In 1972, after graduating from [[Tichon Ironi Alef]] high school, Schreibman was [[Conscription in Israel|drafted]] into the [[Israel Defense Forces|Israeli army]]. In 1973, she won [[Miss Israel|Israel's beauty queen]] [[beauty pageant|contest]]. She was sent as a contestant to the [[Miss Universe]] contest held in Greece in 1973, where she placed fifth. When the competition was over, she returned to the IDF as a clerk for General [[Shmuel Gonen]] who had been promoted to [[Southern Command (Israel)|Southern Command]] of the [[Israel Defense Forces]]. Elkayam, Liat (7 September 2013). [http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/week-s-end/.premium-1.545397 "Miss Israel's journey of fame and terror"], [[Haaretz]] ==Medical career== After completion of her military service, she began to study medicine at [[Sapienza University of Rome]] in Italy. Later, she transferred to the Sackler Faculty of medicine of [[Tel Aviv University]] and graduated with a medical degree. Her dissertation was presented to an international conference in New York and subsequently published in The Journal of Thoracic Cardiovascular Surgery{{citation needed|date=September 2014}}. Schreibman did her [[internship]] at [[Sheba Medical Center]], where she worked for several years. Today she is a member of [[Physicians for Human Rights-Israel]]. Galron-Goldschläger, Joseph. [http://library.osu.edu/projects/hebrew-lexicon/00202 "Limor Sharir-Schreibman"], Modern Hebrew Literature – a Bio-Bibliographical Lexicon Since 2010–2011, she has been the coordinator of a special course at Tel Aviv University's School of Medicine on "literature and medicine."Sharir, Limor (16 October 2010). [http://no666.wordpress.com/2010/10/16/%D7%A8%D7%A4%D7%95%D7%90%D7%94-%D7%95%D7%A1%D7%A4%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%AA-%D7%AA%D7%A8%D7%91%D7%95%D7%99%D7%95%D7%AA-%D7%A0%D7%A4%D7%A8%D7%93%D7%95%D7%AA/ "Literature and Medicine – separate cultures ?"], The Multi-Universe of Eli Eshed Schreibman is a member in the Israeli Organization for Medical Education. [http://healerisrael.wix.com/conference#!conference-program/c1rfe The Israeli Organization for Medical Education establishing conference] ==Literary career== [[File:לימור שריר עם עמוס עוז במהלך קורס ספרות ורפואה.jpg|thumb|Limor Schreibman-Sharir with Israeli novelist [[Amos Oz]]]] Sharir was a [[prose]] advisor for Carmel publishing house. She also sits on the Israeli Council for Culture and Arts in Ministry of Culture and Sport.[http://www.mcs.gov.il/about/AuthoritiesCouncilsCorporations/Israeli%20Council%20for%20the%20Arts/Pages/default.aspx Israeli Council for Culture and Arts members] She is a member of the editing board of "Moznayim" – the monthly Magazine of [[Hebrew Writers Association in Israel]] and the editor of culture and medicine section of the "Reshet Refua" website. [http://library.osu.edu/projects/hebrew-lexicon/00202 Limor Sharir-Shreibman, Modern Hebrew Literature – a Bio-Bibliographical Lexicon] Schreibman-Sharir's book "God and Elvira" published in 2005 in [[Hebrew]], was translated into [[Italian language|Italian]] and published in Italy in 2012. [http://www.poetipoesia.com/collana-di-narrativa-italiana/narrativa-italiana-2012/ "Dio e Elvira" (God and Elvira)], Narrativa Italiana 2012 ==Published works== *'''The House on the Lake''', Yedioth Books. 2004. :Four childhood friends growing up in the villages at the foot of Wolfgang Lake. [[Salzkammergut]] area, [[Austria]] before [[World War II]]. In 1938, the world they knew was changing when [[Anschluss|Germany occupied Austria]], and they became [[Third Reich]] citizens. Reading their thoughts and deeds we learn about the attitude of the Austrians toward [[Jews]] and various ethical and political issues through the eyes of the protagonists, non-Jewish Austrians. *'''God and Elvira''', Carmel Publishing House, 2005. *'''Red Wildberries''', Carmel Publishing House, 2007. :The story takes place in the State of Israel in the 1990s, before the [[1982 Lebanon War]]. Darya, an educated and assertive woman, a lecturer of [[Greek mythology]] at [[Tel Aviv University]] is single, without children and full of contradictions. *'''The Gold and Silver Dunes''', Carmel Publishing House, 2008. :A collection of twenty two stories occurring in different places in Israel ([[Binyamina-Giv'at Ada|Binyamina]], [[Jewish Quarter (Jerusalem)|Jewish Quarter]], south [[Tel Aviv]], [[Hadera]]) and the world (Paris, [[Munich]], Salzburg, [[Palermo]] and [[Marrakesh]]). *'''Menagerie of Fantasies''', Carmel Publishing House, 2009. :The human [[Biological life cycle|life cycle]] described by animals with [[Anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] [[illustration]]s by the author. *'''Marrakesh Secrets''', Carmel Publishing House, 2010. :The plot takes place in the days of king [[Hassan II of Morocco]]. Naim is a twelve-year-old boy living with his parents in [[Marrakesh]]. His father, Mahmud Laishi, a journalist and editor of "Morocco News" was murdered due to his political views. Morocco is depicted as a wild country, full of magic and [[decadence]], sex and submission to the monarchic dictatorship. *'''Martin Buber: Close look – A conversation with Prof. Judith Buber-Agassi"', Carmel Publishing House, 2011. :A biographical-philosophical book based on Limor Sharir's conversations with Prof. Judith Buber-Agassi, [[Martin Buber]]'s granddaughter. This is a personal story about an eminent Jewish family in the German world of the late 19th century and first half of the 20th century.Professor Margolin, Ron (30 September 2009). [http://musaf-shabbat.com/2011/10/05/%D7%91%D7%95%D7%91%D7%A8-%D7%A9%D7%9C%D7%90-%D7%94%D7%9B%D7%A8%D7%AA%D7%9D-%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%9F-%D7%9E%D7%A8%D7%92%D7%95%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9F/ "The Unknown Buber"], [[Makor Rishon]] *'''Reflections – Letters to imaginary heroes in my books and life ''', Carmel Publishing House, 2013. ==See also== *[[Literature of Israel]] *[[Health care in Israel]] == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== * Elkayam, Liat (7 September 2013). [http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/week-s-end/.premium-1.545397 "Miss Israel's journey of fame and terror"], [[Haaretz]] * [http://simania.co.il/authorDetails.php?itemId=1594 Limor Schreibman-Sharir books] in 'Simania' site * [http://www.carmelph.co.il/extensions/virtuemart/browse/108-%D7%9C%D7%99%D7%9E%D7%95%D7%A8-%D7%A9%D7%A8%D7%99%D7%A8?sef=hm Limor Schreibman-Sharir] in Carmel publishing house * Rubin, Noga (June 2013). [http://www.kaye.ac.il/images/files/publications/kolot/2013/kolot6.pdf An intreview with Schreibman-Sharir], Kolot, issue no. 6, pp. 8–10. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140902230231/http://www.mednet.co.il/SiteFiles/1/4519/58781.asp?type=58781 Her articles in "Reshet Refua"] {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schreibman-Sharir, Limor}} [[Category:Beauty pageant contestants]] [[Category:Israeli Jews]] [[Category:Israeli novelists]] [[Category:Israeli physicians]] [[Category:Israeli women novelists]] [[Category:Israeli women physicians]] [[Category:Jewish novelists]] [[Category:Miss Israel winners]] [[Category:Miss Universe 1973 contestants]] [[Category:People from Tel Aviv]] [[Category:Tel Aviv University alumni]] [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

page.title: List of defunct comic book conventions

revision.text:
This is a '''list''' of noteworthy '''defunct [[comic book convention]]s'''<ref group="nb" name="noteworthy"/> (as distinct from [[List of anime conventions|anime conventions]], [[List of furry conventions|furry conventions]], [[List of gaming conventions|gaming conventions]], [[horror convention]]s, [[List of multigenre conventions|multigenre conventions]], and [[List of science fiction conventions|science fiction conventions]]). This a companion to [[List of comic book conventions]]. {{TOC right|limit=3}}
== Africa ==
=== Ivory Coast === * [[Coco Bulles]] (2001–2007)
== Europe ==
=== United Kingdom === * [[British Comic Art Convention]], England (1968–1981) * [[Comic Expo]] (Bristol International Comic & Small Press Expo), Bristol, England (2004–2014) — successor to [[Comic Festival]] * [[Comic Festival]], Bristol, England (1999–2004) — began as "Comic 99" * [[Comic Mart]], London (1972–c. 1984) * [[Hi-Ex]], Inverness, Scotland (2008–2012) * [[United Kingdom Comic Art Convention]] (UKCAC), London, England (1985–1998) — final convention took place in Manchester
== North America ==
=== Canada === * [[Toronto Comic Con]], Toronto (2003–2012) — acquired by Wizard Entertainment in 2009
=== United States === * [[Academy Con]], New York City (1965–1967) * [[Adventure Con]], Knoxville, Tennessee (2002–2012) * [[Atlanta Fantasy Fair]], Atlanta (1975–1995) * [[Boston Comic Con]], Boston (2007–2017) * [[Comic Art Convention]], New York City (1968–1983) — also held in Philadelphia from 1977–1979 * [[Comix Fair]], Houston (1983–c. 1996) — replaced the defunct [[Houstoncon]] * [[Creation Entertainment|Creation Con]], New York City (1971–1988) — variously named "Big Comicon Creation Convention," "Creation Comic Book & Pop Culture Convention," "Creation '78,", etc. * [[Dallas Fantasy Fair]], Dallas (1982–1995) * [[Detroit Triple Fan Fair]], Detroit (1965–1978) * [[FantaCon]], Albany, New York (1979–1990; 2013) * [[Houstoncon]], Houston (1967–1982) * [[Magnum Opus Con]], Georgia and South Carolina (1986–2001) * [[Metro Con]], Washington. D.C. (1970–1971) — produced by teenager [[Gary Groth]]; attendees included [[Phil Seuling]], [[Bud Plant]], and [[Dave Cockrum]]<ref name=WashPost>Jacobson, Aileen. "Serious Comics Fans," ''Washington Post'' (August 16, 1971), p. B2.</ref> * [[Multicon]], Oklahoma City (1970–1982) * [[New York International Sci-Fi and Fantasy Creators Convention]], [[Madison Square Garden]], New York City (1999–2000) * [[OrlandoCon]], Orlando (1974–1994) * [[Ramapo Comic Con]] (1987–c. 1998), [[Ramapo High School (New York)|Ramapo High School]], Spring Valley, New York — sponsored by the Ramapo High School Comic Book Club; known for its annual roster of high-profile comic creator guests<ref>Rimmels, Beth Hannan. [http://www.comicsutra.com/cs/stripped/strippedv2i5.htm "Stripped: Cruising in Queens, Etc.,"] ''Long Island Voice'' (May 14–20, 1998).</ref> * [[Stumptown Comics Fest]], Portland, Oregon (2004–2013) * [[UnCommonCon]], Dallas (2000–2001) * [[Wildcat Comic Con]], Williamsport, Pennsylvania (2012–2014)
==Notes== <references group="nb"> <ref name="noteworthy">A convention is presumed noteworthy if it has received significant coverage in [[Wikipedia:Reliable sources|reliable sources]] that are [[Wikipedia:Verifiability#Sources|independent]] of the convention and satisfies the [[Wikipedia:Notability|inclusion criteria]] for a stand-alone article. Other conditions may apply.</ref> </references>

{{lowercase}} {{unreferenced|date=April 2008}} {{Infobox company |name = magnussoft Deutschland GmbH |logo= |foundation = 1984 (magnussoft)
2004 (magnussoft Deutschland GmbH) |type = GmbH |location_city = [[Kesselsdorf]] |location_country=[[Germany]] |industry= [[Video game industry|Interactive entertainment]] |homepage = [http://www.magnussoft.com/ www.magnussoft.com] }} '''magnussoft''' Deutschland GmbH is a pan-European computer game developer and [[publisher]]. The company is seated near Dresden in the eastern region of Germany. However, magnussoft does not publish outside of Europe, they leave that work to local companies. In Europe magnussoft are well known, primarily for their releases of collections of software for 8-Bit computer systems that were very popular in the 1980s: [[Commodore 64]], Commodore [[Amiga]], Atari XL/XE, and [[Atari ST]]. All required emulators are included so the software work on ordinary PCs although the programs are unaltered. There is a general collection called ''Retro-Classix'' that covers a bit of everything and collections that specialize on one particular system, like the ''Amiga Classix'' or the ''C64 Classix''. Several successors followed. The company released more than 160 products over the past ten years. Among their assortment are adventure games, board games, strategic games as well as shoot´em up games and jump and runs. On the other hand, magnussoft also released computer applications and educational software. The software was brought under varied labels to the market in Germany, Austria, Switzerland, the Benelux countries, France, Great Britain, and the United States of America. By 2008 magnussoft have gained access to the software market, especially in the lower budget and middle price range. They cooperate with acquainted German partners like for example "ak tronik Software & Services", "KOCH Media", and the "Verlagsgruppe Weltbild". In addition magnussoft has founded more subsidiaries in other parts of Europe. magnussoft have created their profile through the release of [[Magnussoft ZETA|ZETA]], a broad range of retro games, and classic computer games like Aquanoid, Barkanoid or Plot's. [[Image:Magnussoft Firmensitz Kesselsdorf-20110402.jpg|thumb|upright=1.6|The headquarters of Magnussoft in Kesselsdorf]] == Games (selection) == * Amiga Classix * Aquanoid * Barkanoid * Boulder Match * Break It * C64 Classix * Colossus Chess * Dr. Tool Serie * Fix & Foxi Serie * Jacks Crazy Cong * Jump Jack * KLIX * METRIS * MiniGolf * Packs Serie * PLOTS! * Pool Island * Retro-Classix * Sokoman == Applications (selection) == * Dr Brain series * Dr. Tool series * Driver Cataloger * Easy Bootmanager * Typing Tutor == Educational software (selection) == * Deutsch, Englisch und Mathe für Zwerge * Deutsch– und Mathe Compilation * Fahrschule == Criticism == In 2006 magnussoft incurred public criticism for ceasing the distribution and the funding of [[BeOS]] replacement [[Magnussoft ZETA|Magnussoft Zeta]] OS because of its uncertain legal status. == Trademarks == * Amiga Classix * Aquanoid * Barkanoid * C64 Classix * Dr. Brain * Dr. Tool * Retro Classix == External links == * [http://www.magnussoft.com/ magnussoft] - official website == References == {{reflist}} {{BeOS}} [[Category:Video game publishers]] [[Category:Video game companies of Germany]] [[Category:Companies based in Saxony]] [[Category:BeOS]] [[Category:Wilsdruff]]

{{Use American English|date=April 2015}} {{good article}} {{Infobox song | name = Man Down | cover = Man Down.png | alt = A black and white image of wearing oversized sunglasses with "Man Down" written vertically on the right hand side | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[Rihanna]] | album = [[Loud (Rihanna album)|Loud]] | released = {{start date|2011|05|03}} | format = {{hlist|[[Music download|Digital download]]}} | recorded = {{hlist|[[The Village (studio)|The Village]]|[[Westlake Recording Studios]]}} | studio = | venue = | genre = [[Reggae]] | length = {{Duration|m=4|s=28}} | label = {{Flat list| *[[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]] *SRP}} | writer = {{hlist|Shama Joseph|[[Rock City (duo)|Timothy Thomas]]|[[Rock City (duo)|Theron Thomas]]|[[Shontelle|Shontelle Layne]]}} | producer = {{hlist|Sham|[[Kuk Harrell]]|Bobby Campbell}} | prev_title = [[S&M (song)|S&M]] | prev_year = 2011 | next_title = [[California King Bed]] | next_year = 2011 }}
"'''Man Down'''" is a song by Barbadian singer, [[Rihanna]] from her fifth studio album, ''[[Loud (Rihanna album)|Loud]]'' (2010). Singer [[Shontelle]] and production duo [[Rock City (duo)|Rock City]] wrote the song with its main producer, Sham. They wrote it during a writing camp, in Los Angeles of March 2010, held by Rihanna's record label to gather compositions for possible inclusion on the then-untitled album. Rock City were inspired by [[Bob Marley]]'s 1973 song "[[I Shot the Sheriff]]" and set out to create a song which embodied the same feel, but from a female perspective. "Man Down" is a [[reggae]] song which incorporates elements of [[ragga]] and [[electronic music]]. Lyrically, Rihanna is a [[fugitive]] after she shoots a man, an action she later regrets. Several critics singled out "Man Down" as ''Loud''{{'}}s highlight, while others commented on her prominent West Indian accent and vocal agility.
[[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]] released "Man Down" on May 3, 2011, as the fifth single from the album. In the United States, the single reached number 59 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and number 9 on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]] chart. It has been certified double platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). The song topped the chart in France for five consecutive weeks and reached the top three in Belgium and the Netherlands. [[Anthony Mandler]] directed its music video, in which Rihanna's character shoots a man after he [[rape]]s her. The video was criticized by the [[Parents Television Council]], Industry Ears and Mothers Against Violence, who faulted Rihanna for suggesting that murder is an acceptable form of justice for rape victims. However, actress [[Gabrielle Union]], a rape victim, praised the video for being relatable. "Man Down" was on the [[set list]] for three of Rihanna's tours – the [[Loud Tour]] (2011), the [[Diamonds World Tour]] (2013) and the [[Anti World Tour]] (2016).
==Background== In March 2010, record label [[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]] held a writing camp in Los Angeles for songwriters and producers to compose material for possible inclusion on [[Rihanna]]'s then-untitled fifth studio album, ''[[Loud (Rihanna album)|Loud]]''.<ref name="HipHopDX">{{cite web|last=Ketchum III|first=William|url=http://hiphopdx.com/news/id.18167/title.sak-pase-reveals-queens-influence-on-watch-the-throne-tracks-rihannas-man-down-controversy|title=Sak Pase Reveals Queen's Influence On 'Watch The Throne' Tracks, Rihanna's 'Man Down' Controversy|work=[[HipHopDX]]|date=January 3, 2012|accessdate=August 20, 2015}}</ref><ref name="NRP">{{cite web|last=Chace|first=Zoe|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/money/2011/07/05/137530847/how-much-does-it-cost-to-make-a-hit-song|title=How Much Does It Cost To Make A Hit Song?|work=[[NPR]]|date=June 30, 2011|accessdate=August 20, 2015}}</ref> Def Jam rented out nearly every recording studio in Los Angeles in order to create as many songs as possible.<ref name="HipHopDX"/> Ray Daniels, the manager of musical duo [[Rock City (musical duo)|Rock City]] (brothers Theron and Timothy Thomas), was present during the sessions, and stated that a writing camp typically involves the label hiring ten recording studios for two weeks at the cost of $25,000 per day.<ref name="NRP"/> Daniels revealed that it is where songwriters have lyrics but no music, and where producers have music but no lyrics.<ref name="NRP"/>
[[Shama Joseph]], professionally known as Sham, was hired as one of the producers to work on crafting songs at the camp.<ref name="HipHopDX"/> Sham's manager had arranged his attendance at the camp through an acquaintance who was an employee of the record label. Sham explained that he found a flight to Los Angeles and began working on music as soon as he arrived, stating that he had "nothing to lose and everything to gain".<ref name="HipHopDX"/> He was inspired by a vision of Rihanna performing songs at a concert that were Caribbean themed.<ref name="HipHopDX"/> Sham felt that Rihanna had not explored Caribbean-themed music since her debut album, ''[[Music of the Sun]]'' (2005).<ref name="HipHopDX"/>
==Production and recording== [[File:Bob-Marley.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.65|alt=Bob Marley onstage with a guitar|[[Rock City (production duo)|Rock City]] wanted to recreate [[Bob Marley]]'s ''(pictured)'' 1973 song "[[I Shot the Sheriff]]" from a female perspective.]] According to Daniels, Rock City knew Sham but they had not heard the West Indian/Caribbean-themed music that he had composed during the camp. Sham played the music to them, to which the brothers responded "Let's give Rihanna a one-drop! Like, a response to 'I shot the sheriff'!"<ref name="NRP"/> Together, Sham and Rock City wrote the lyrics to "Man Down" in twelve minutes.<ref name="NRP"/> In an [[MTV News]] interview, Rock City said they intended to write a song that would embody [[Bob Marley]]'s "[[I Shot the Sheriff]]" (1973) from a female perspective and to "tap [Rihanna's] island origins in a way that sounded authentic".<ref name="RockCity MTV Interview">{{cite web|last=Thomas|first=Rebecca|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1665450/rihanna-man-down-bob-marley/|title=Rihanna’s ‘Man Down’ Is Her Answer To Bob Marley Classic|work=[[MTV News]]|date=June 6, 2011|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref><ref name="NME Rock City Interview">{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/rihanna/57210|title=Rihanna's 'Man Down' is 'answer to Bob Marley's 'I Shot The Sheriff'|work=[[NME]]|date=June 10, 2011|accessdate=April 15, 2015}}</ref> Singer [[Shontelle]] said that Rihanna called her during the [[Last Girl on Earth]] tour and asked her to be involved with the song. She confirmed that Rihanna was present when she was writing her part in the recording studio.<ref>{{cite web|last=Nissim|first=Maya|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a307989/shontelle-glad-leona-turned-down-song.html#~pbmOEp7iJO3v6e|title=Shontelle 'glad Leona turned down song'|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=March 9, 2011|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Shonetelle explains">{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2010/11/08/new-music-rihanna-california-king-bed-man-down/|title=New Music: Rihanna - 'California King Bed' and 'Man Down'|work=[[Rap-Up]]|date=November 8, 2010|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref> Shontelle elucidated that following one of Rihanna's concerts, the singer exited the stage and immediately returned to the tour bus to work in the studio.<ref name="Shonetelle explains"/> Daniels said that once the writing camp had concluded, Rihanna listened to all of the songs which had been composed for her and chose her favorites.<ref name="NRP"/> In September 2010, several months after Sham attended the writing camp, Rihanna called him and said that she wanted to record "Man Down" for inclusion on ''Loud''.<ref name="HipHopDX"/>
Rihanna later described the sentiment she wanted to express as "gangsta", and elaborated on how reggae culture has influenced her musical style: "I'm super inspired by reggae music [and it] has been a part of me since I was born, and I grew up listening to it. I was exciting for me to take this on as my own and do a song like this, especially with the lyrics being like that."<ref name="Rihanna MTV Interview">{{cite web|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1652415/rihanna-says-louds-man-down-is-gangsta/|title=Rihanna Says Loud‘s ‘Man Down’ Is ‘Gangsta’|work=MTV News|date=November 16, 2010|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> The track was composed during Rihanna's Last Girl on Earth tour. The song's instrumental was recorded by Cary Clark at [[The Village (studio)|The Village]] in Los Angeles. [[Kuk Harrell]] produced Rihanna's vocals with Josh Gudwin and Marcos Tovar at [[Westlake Recording Studios]], also in Los Angeles. Bobby Campbell assisted with vocal production and recording. The song was [[Audio mixing (recorded music)|mixed]] by [[Manny Marroquin]] at Larrabee Sound Studios in Los Angeles, assisted by Erik Madrid and Christian Plata.<ref name="LoudNotes">{{cite AV media notes|title=[[Loud (Rihanna album)|Loud]]|date=November 12, 2010|others=[[Rihanna]]|page=5|type=Inlay cover|work=''[[Def Jam Recordings]]''}}</ref>
Daniels estimated the total cost of the writing camp to be approximately $200,000, averaging $18,000 for each of the eleven songs which were included on ''Loud''; the camp consisted of forty writers and producers.<ref name="NRP"/> Daniels confirmed that Rock City received $15,000 and Sham $20,000 for their part in the production of "Man Down". He said that "to get that twelve minutes of inspiration from a top songwriting team is expensive — even before you take into account the fee for the songwriters".<ref name="NRP"/> A cost of $53,000 for "Man Down" was already incurred prior to Rihanna entering the studio with a vocal producer.<ref name="NRP"/> Although [[Makeba Riddick]] did not serve as the song's vocal producer, Daniels cited her as an example of how the process works and how much she would charge. It is the responsibility of the vocal producer to tell a singer how to sing the song correctly to achieve the desired sound.<ref name="NRP"/> Daniels said that Riddick's fee varies from $10,000 to $15,000, and that the final part of the process is for the song to be mixed and mastered, which incurs a similar fee. He estimated the final cost of writing, producing, vocal producing, mixing and mastering "Man Down" to be $78,000.<ref name="NRP"/> When combined with the marketing and promotional costs, the total expense was $1,078,000.<ref name="Million Cost">{{cite web|last=McCormick|first=Neil|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopfeatures/11619043/How-many-songwriters-does-it-take-to-change-a-chorus.html|title=How many songwriters does it take to change a chorus?|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=May 21, 2015|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref>
==Composition and lyrical interpretation== [[File:Chris Brown 2, 2012.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.85|August Brown of ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' saw "Man Down" as a warning to Rihanna's ex-boyfriend [[Chris Brown]] ''(pictured)''.<ref name="LA Times"/>|alt=A man wearing a purple vest and cap.]] "Man Down" is a reggae<ref name="Baltimore"/> [[murder ballad]]<ref name="LA Times"/> with "Caribbean-rhythms" and elements of [[ragga]] and [[electronic music]].<ref name="BBC Review">{{cite news|last=Skinner|first=James|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/x5fd|title= Review: ''Loud''|work=[[BBC]]|date=November 15, 2010|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref><ref name="EW">{{cite web|last=Greenblatt|first=Leah|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2010/11/10/loud|title=Review: ''Loud''|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=November 11, 2010|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref><ref name="NY Times">{{cite news|last=Pareles|first=Jon|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/16/arts/music/16choice.html|title=Critics’ Choice: New CDs|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=November 15, 2010|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Cinquemani">{{cite web|last=Cinquemani|first=Sal|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/review/rihanna-loud/2312|title=Review: ''Loud''|work=[[Slant Magazine]]|date=November 12, 2010|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> The song, in the [[Key (music)|key]] of [[C minor]], has a tempo of 77 [[tempo|beats per minute]].<ref name="sheet">{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtd.asp?ppn=MN0096597|title=dig Sheet Music, Rihanna 'Man Down'|year=2010|work=''Musicnotes. [[Peer International (music publishing)|Peer International Music Publishing]]''|id=MN0089403|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> Rihanna's voice spans more than one and a half [[octave]]s, from F<sub>3</sub> to E{{music|flat}}<sub>5</sub>.<ref name="sheet"/> [[Slant Magazine]] critic Sal Cinquemani described "Man Down" as one of Rihanna's "most confident vocal performances" with her strong Barbadian [[patois]].<ref name="BBC Review"/><ref name="Cinquemani"/> [[Jon Pareles]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' said that the singer "plays up her West Indian accent",<ref name="NY Times"/> and August Brown of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' described the vocals as reasserting "her Caribbean lilt".<ref name="LA Times">{{cite news|last=Brown|first=August|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2010/11/album-review-rihannas-loud.html|title=Critics’ Choice: New CDs|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 16, 2010|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' writer Leah Greenblatt described "Man Down" as a song with "island rhythms".<ref name="EW"/> Lyrically, Rihanna is a [[fugitive]] after she shoots a man, but later regrets it.<ref name="Cinquemani"/><ref name="Pitchfork">{{cite web|last=Dombal|first=Ryan|url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/14897-loud/|title=Rihanna – Loud|work=[[Pitchfork Media]]|date=November 24, 2010|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Context">{{cite web|author=[[Kitty Empire]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/oct/09/rihanna-o2-london-live-review|title=Rihanna – review|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=October 9, 2011|accessdate=August 20, 2015}}</ref> Rihanna slowly relays the chain of events which led up to the murder.<ref name="MuuMuse">{{cite web|last=Stern|first=Bradley|url=http://www.muumuse.com/2010/11/rihanna-loud-album-review.html/|title=Rihanna: Loud (Album Review)|work=[[MuuMuse]]|date=November 15, 2010|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref> She cries to her mother about the act that she has committed – "Mama, I just shot a man down" – expressing guilt and remorse for not meaning to kill her attacker, and that he is somebody's son.<ref>{{cite web|last=Duke|first=Alan|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/SHOWBIZ/celebrity.news.gossip/06/02/rihanna.man.down.controversy/|title=Rihanna's 'Man Down' video 'inexcusable,' parent group says|work=[[CNN]]|date=June 3, 2011|accessdate=August 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Contactmusic"/> As the track develops, Rihanna's [[Bajan Creole|Bajan]] accent becomes stronger and exaggerated, which climaxes during the [[Bridge (music)|bridge]] as she declares "Why deed I pull dee treeguh, pull dee treeguh, pull dee treeguh, BOOM!"<ref name="MuuMuse"/> [[MuuMuse]] writer Bradley Stern thought that the track took on a [[confessional]] tone.<ref name="MuuMuse"/>
On February 8, 2009, Rihanna was reported to have been involved in an altercation with her boyfriend, [[Chris Brown]]. He allegedly punched Rihanna and threatened to kill her. Brown turned himself in to the police and pleaded guilty to [[misdemeanor assault]] during the trial.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Lee|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20263113,00.html|title=Chris Brown Charged with Two Felonies in Rihanna Beating|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=March 5, 2009|accessdate=August 19, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kaufman|first=Gil|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1606481/chris-brown-police-report-provides-details-of-altercation/|title=Chris Brown Police Report Provides Details Of Altercation|work=MTV News|date=March 6, 2009|accessdate=August 19, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Chris-Brown-Due-Back-in-DC-Court-for-Plea-Hearing-273531501.html|title=Chris Brown Pleads Guilty to Assault in Washington|work=NBC Washington|date=September 2, 2014|accessdate=August 19, 2015}}</ref> August Brown called the song an apparent "warning" to Chris Brown and a response to his song "[[Deuces (song)|Deuces]]" (2010),<ref name="LA Times"/> which denounces an ex-lover.<ref name="LA Times FAME">{{cite news|last=Brown|first=August|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2011/03/album-review-chris-browns-fame.html|title=Album Review: Chris Brown 'F.A.M.E'|work=Los Angeles Times|date=March 22, 2011|accessdate=July 27, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Rytlewski|first=Evan|url=http://www.avclub.com/review/chris-brown-ifamei-53462|title=Chris Brown: F.A.ME.|work=[[The A.V. Club]]|date=March 22, 2011|accessdate=July 27, 2015}}</ref> [[Kitty Empire]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' wrote that Brown's assault on Rihanna gives the song lyrical context, and that Rihanna sings the song with "bittersweet menace."<ref name="Context"/> When asked by [[HipHopDX]] about how he reacted to listeners of the song saying that it condones violence, Sham dismissed the accusations:
{{quote|style=margin-left: 0; margin-right: 0; padding-left: 2.8em; padding-right: 2.8em;|1=I didn’t think it made any sense. I think it was because of who it was saying 'I just shot a man down.' I think it was very hypocritical for some of the parents against violence in media, those same parents have probably allowed their kids to watch all types of movies and programs that have depictions, or things that insinuate violence. So for them to be mad about, number one, an issue that actually exists? ... A woman feeling like she wants to shoot somebody who’s still alive because of something that they took from her, that’s real and that’s honest. So the emotion is a very true emotion ... and they relive it on a daily basis. I think it was crazy and blown out of proportion .... But people benefit from controversy, and those same people who probably were trying to bring awareness, now they have a voice and now they’re 'specialists,' and they can speak for a group of people all of a sudden.<ref name="HipHopDX"/>}} {{clear}}
==Release and reception== On March 1, 2011, Rihanna asked fans to help her choose the next single from ''Loud'' using [[Twitter]], saying that she would film a music video in the forthcoming weeks. After an influx of suggestions, the singer said she had narrowed the options down to four songs: "Man Down", "[[California King Bed]]", "[[Cheers (Drink to That)]]" and "[[Fading (song)|Fading]]".<ref>{{cite web|last=Corner|first=Lewis|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a306542/rihanna-asks-fans-to-choose-next-single.html#~pbmn2Q37ApCRz8|title=Rihanna asks fans to choose next single|work=Digital Spy|date=March 1, 2011|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> On March 12, she confirmed that "California King Bed" had been selected as the next international single.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com.au/music/sitecomponent/a28814/singles-release-diary.html |title=Singles Release Diary |work=Digital Spy |date=May 5, 2011 |accessdate=April 30, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yRMEHEvD?url=http://www.digitalspy.com.au/music/sitecomponent/a28814/singles-release-diary.html |archivedate=May 4, 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Copsey|first=Robert|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a308595/rihanna-announces-next-single.html|title=Rihanna announces next single|work=Digital Spy|date=March 12, 2011|accessdate=April 15, 2015}}</ref> However, "Man Down" was sent to [[Rhythmic contemporary|rhythmic]] and [[Urban contemporary|urban]] radio stations in the United States on May 3,<ref>{{cite web|last=Corner|first=Lewis|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a316646/rihanna-switches-new-single-release-dates.html#~piCFqiRLBH15S6|title=Rihanna switches new single release dates?|work=Digital Spy|date=April 27, 2011|accessdate=July 16, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Urban">{{cite web|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yPorUcGl?url=http://www.allaccess.com/urban/future-releases |url=http://www.allaccess.com/urban/future-releases |title=Impacting Songs – Urban Radio |work=All Access Music Group |archivedate=May 3, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="Rhythmic">{{cite web|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yFf2i1Mx?url=http://www.allaccess.com/top40-rhythmic/future-releases |url=http://www.allaccess.com/top40-rhythmic/future-releases |title=Impacting Songs – Rhythmic Radio |work=All Access Music Group |archivedate=April 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> before the May 13 release of "California King Bed", making "Man Down" and "California King Bed" the fifth and sixth singles from ''Loud''.<ref name="CKB Release">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/dk/album/california-king-bed/id437261352?i=437261353&ign-mpt=uo%3D2|title=California King Bed – Single Denmark iTunes|work=iTunes Store (DK)|accessdate=May 27, 2015}}</ref> The song was released in France and Switzerland on July 11<ref name="FRANCE">{{cite web|url=https://fr.7digital.com/artist/rihanna/release/man-down-1/?h=01&src=live-search|title=Man Down (Explicit) – Rihanna|work=[[7digital]]|date=July 7, 2011|accessdate=April 30, 2015|language=French}}</ref><ref name="SWISS">{{cite web|url=https://de-ch.7digital.com/artist/rihanna/release/man-down-1/?h=01&src=live-search|title=Man Down (Explicit) – Rihanna|work=7digital|date=July 7, 2011|accessdate=April 30, 2015|language=Swiss German}}</ref> and the Netherlands on July 15.<ref name="NETHERLANDS">{{cite web|url=https://nl.7digital.com/artist/rihanna/release/man-down-1/?h=01&src=live-search|title=Man Down (Explicit) – Rihanna|work=7digital|date=July 15, 2011|accessdate=April 30, 2015|language=Dutch}}</ref>
Kitty Empire called the track "excellent", and praised it for being an original composition which is reminiscent of a "righteous old reggae murder ballad".<ref name="Context"/> ''[[Consequence of Sound]]'' writer Ryan Burleson said that "Man Down" and another album track called "[[Fading (song)|Fading]]" both "stand on their own sonically", and that the former is an [[Homage (arts)|homage]] to her Caribbean heritage with its dancehall melody.<ref>{{cite web|last=Burleson|first=Ryan|url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2010/11/album-review-rihanna-loud/|title=Rihanna – Loud|work=[[Consequence of Sound]]|date=November 22, 2010|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref> Describing the track as "breezy", Bradley Stern thought that no other song on ''Loud'' embodied Rihanna's personality more so than on "Man Down".<ref name="MuuMuse"/> Cinquemani chose "Man Down" as the best song on ''Loud'', calling Rihanna's vocal agility "surprising" and noting that the "fully-fledged reggae" song is co-written by a fellow Barbadian-born singer, Shontelle.<ref name="Cinquemani"/>
In her review of ''Loud'', Emily Mackay of ''[[NME]]'' called its experimentation more "organic" than that on Rihanna's previous album ''[[Rated R (Rihanna album)|Rated R]]'' (2009), citing "Man Down{{"'}}s theme of "doomed youth".<ref>{{cite web|last=Mackay|first=Emily|url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/rihanna/11718|title=Review: ''Loud''|work=[[NME]]|date=November 12, 2010|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> Similarly, Nima Baniamer of [[Contactmusic.com]] pointed out that "Man Down", which she described as "a dark track" that is "haunting" yet "delightfully intriguing", was reminiscent of the material on ''Rated R''.<ref name="Contactmusic">{{cite web|last=Baniamer|first=Nima|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/rihanna/music/rihanna-loud|title=Rihanna - Loud Album Review|work=[[Contactmusic.com]]|date=December 2, 2010|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref> In their review of Rihanna's top 20 songs, ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]'' ranked "Man Down" as their tenth best track, writing that it is Rihanna at "her badass best".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Levine|first1=Nick|last2=Manning|first2=James|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/music/best-rihanna-songs|title=The 20 best Rihanna songs|work=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]|date=May 15, 2015|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref> ''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]'' staff compiled a list of their top 26 Rihanna songs, and ranked "Man Down" in thirteenth place; Claire Lobenfeld thought that it was the singers most "cinematic" song of her career, and that she elevated the theme of "accidental manslaughter" from "downtrodden" to "adorable".<ref>{{cite web|last=Lobenfeld|first=Claire|url=http://uk.complex.com/music/2014/02/best-rihanna-songs/man-down|title=The 26 Best Rihanna Songs|work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|date=February 20, 2014|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref>
==Commercial performance== In the United States, "Man Down" debuted on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 at number 94 on June 1, 2011, peaking at number 59<ref name="Hot 100 Chart Beat">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/470906/idols-scotty-mccreery-lauren-alaina-top-hot-100-debuts-adele-still-no-1|title='Idols' Scotty McCreery & Lauren Alaina Top Hot 100 Debuts, Adele Still No. 1|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=June 1, 2011|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Rihanna Hot 100 Chart History Billboard">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/365068/rihanna/chart?page=1&f=379|title=Rihanna Chart History – The Hot 100|work=Billboard|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref> and spending a total of 14 weeks on the chart.<ref name="Rihanna Hot 100 Chart History Billboard"/> On the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]] chart, it peaked at number 9 on August 6, 2011, remaining there for 2 weeks<ref name="R&B Hip hop peak 1">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/r-b-hip-hop-songs/2011-08-06?order=gainer|title=Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs – Week of August 6, 2011|work=Billboard|date=July 6, 2011|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref><ref name="R&B Hip hop peak 2">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/r-b-hip-hop-songs/2011-08-13?order=gainer|title=Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs – Week of August 13, 2011|work=Billboard|date=July 13, 2011|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref> and spending a total of 19 weeks charting.<ref name="Rihanna R&B Hip hop Chart History Billboard">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/365068/rihanna/chart?page=1&f=367|title=Rihanna Chart History – Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|work=Billboard|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref> It was number 47 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs 2011 year-end list.<ref name="R&B Hip hop year end">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/365068/rihanna/chart?f=416|title=Rihanna Chart History – Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs 2011 Year End Chart|work=Billboard|year=2011|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref> The track peaked at number 56 on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay]] chart,<ref name="Rihanna R&B Hip hop Airplay Chart History Billboard">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/365068/rihanna/chart?page=1&f=364|title=Rihanna Chart History – Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay|work=Billboard|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref> number 20 on the Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Digital Songs chart<ref name="Rihanna R&B Hip hop Digital Chart History Billboard">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/365068/rihanna/chart?page=1&f=1086|title=Rihanna Chart History – Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Digital Songs|work=Billboard|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref> and number 40 on the [[Hot 100 Airplay (Radio Songs)|Radio Songs]] chart.<ref name="Rihanna Radio Songs Chart History Billboard">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/365068/rihanna/chart?page=1&f=350|title=Rihanna Chart History – Radio Songs|work=Billboard|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref> "Man Down" was certified double platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA), denoting shipments of more than 2 million units.<ref name="USCert"/> The song reached number 92 on the [[Canadian Hot 100]].<ref name="Man Down Canadian Hot 100">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/365068/rihanna/chart?page=1&f=793|title=Canadian Hot 100 Chart History|work=Billboard|accessdate=May 1, 2015}}</ref>
"Man Down" debuted at number 65 on the [[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique|French Singles Chart]] on June 6, 2011, a month before its release as a single.<ref name="FRANCE"/><ref name="French Charts">{{cite web|url=http://lescharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Rihanna&titel=Man+Down&cat=s|title=Rihanna – Man Down (Chanson)|work=Hung Medien|accessdate=May 29, 2015|language=French}}</ref> It rose to number 1 on July 30, remaining there for 5 consecutive weeks, and was number 2 the week before and for 3 weeks after its chart-topping run.<ref name="French Charts"/> It stayed on the chart until May 12, 2012, but re-entered three weeks later.<ref name="French Charts"/> The song, on and off the French chart for the rest the year, continued to appear on it sporadically in 2013.<ref name="French Charts"/> After a total of 73 weeks on the chart, the track's last French chart appearance was at number 172 on August 8, 2013.<ref name="French Charts"/>
In the United Kingdom, "Man Down" entered the [[UK Singles Chart|Singles Chart]] at number 117 on June 11, 2015,<ref name="UKDebut117">{{cite web|url=http://www.zobbel.de/cluk/121201cluk.txt|title=Chart: CLUK Update 11.06.2011 (wk22) – Chart Log UK: New Entries Update|work=Zobbel|date=June 11, 2011|accessdate=May 29, 2015}}</ref> reaching Company|date=July 10, 2011|accessdate=May 29, 2015}}</ref> and spending a total of 11 weeks on the chart.<ref name="Man Down Peak">{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/12203/rihanna/|title=Rihanna Singles Chart History|work=Official Chart Company|accessdate=May 29, 2015}}</ref> On the [[UK R&B Chart]], "Man Down" reached number 15 on June 26, spending 18 weeks in the top 40.<ref name="Man Down R&B Peak">{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/charts/r-and-b-singles-chart/20110626/114|title=Official R&B Singles Chart Top 40 – 26 June 2011 – 02 July 2011|work=Official Chart Company|date=June 26, 2011|accessdate=May 29, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/charts/r-and-b-singles-chart/20111009/114|title=Official R&B Singles Chart Top 40 – 09 October 2011 – 15 October 2011|work=Official Chart Company|date=October 9, 2011|accessdate=May 29, 2015}}</ref> In Belgium, the song peaked at number 3 in Dutch-speaking Flanders<ref name="Flanders">{{cite web|url=http://www.ultratop.be/nl/song/b8ac3/Rihanna-Man-Down|title=Rihanna – Man Down|work=[[Ultratop]]|accessdate=June 3, 2015|language=Dutch}}</ref> and number 2 in French-speaking Wallonia.<ref name="Wallonia">{{cite web|url=http://www.ultratop.be/fr/song/b8ac3/Rihanna-Man-Down|title=Rihanna – Man Down|work=Ultratop|accessdate=June 3, 2015|language=French}}</ref> It was certified gold by the [[Belgian Entertainment Association]] (BEA) for selling more than 15,000 copies.<ref name="BEA">{{cite web|url=http://www.ultratop.be/nl/certifications.asp?year=2011|title=Gold and Platinum – Singles 2011|work=[[Belgian Entertainment Association]]|accessdate=June 3, 2015|language=Dutch}}</ref> Although the song spent only 1 week on the Italian Singles Chart (at number 8), it was certified platinum web|url=http://www.italiancharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Rihanna&titel=Man+Down&cat=s|title=Rihanna – Man Down (Song)|work=[[Federazione Industria Musicale Italiana]]|accessdate=June 3, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Italy Cert">{{cite web|url=http://www.fimi.it/certificazioni#/category:singoli/year:2014/page:0/term:RIhanna|title=Certificazioni|work=Federazione Industria Musicale Italiana|accessdate=June 3, 2015|language=Italian}}</ref>
==Music video==
===Background and synopsis===
[[Anthony Mandler]] directed the music video for "Man Down" in April 2011 on a beach in [[Portland Parish]], on the northeastern [[Jamaica]]n coast.<ref name="Video location">{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2011/05/30/rihanna-sends-strong-message-in-man-down-video/|title=Rihanna sends strong message in 'Man Down' video|work=Rap-Up|date=May 30, 2011|accessdate=June 2, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Mandler 1">{{cite web|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1663924/rihanna-man-down-music-video/|title=Rihanna Director Talks Upcoming 'Man Down' Video|work=MTV News|date=May 16, 2011|accessdate=June 2, 2015}}</ref> Rihanna told ''[[Rap-Up]]'' that the video has a "strong underlying message [for] girls like me!"<ref name="Video location"/> On May 1, 2011, three [[camera phone]] [[Teaser campaign|teaser]] photos, of Rihanna on a beach in a white [[Dolce & Gabbana]] dress and riding a bicycle in Portland Parish, were released.<ref name="Teaser photos">{{cite web|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2011/05/01/rihanna-shoots-man-down-video-in-jamaica/|title=Rihanna Shoots 'Man Down' Video in Jamaica|work=Rap-Up|date=May 1, 2011|accessdate=June 2, 2015}}</ref> The music video premiered on [[Black Entertainment Television (BET)|BET]]'s ''[[106 & Park]]'' on May 31, 2011.<ref name="Video location"/> In an interview for [[MTV News]], Mandler said that "Man Down" required "a strong narrative and visual" and that fans could expect something "dramatic and shocking and intense and emotions and uplifting and enlightening".<ref name="Mandler 1"/>
The video opens as the protagonist (Rihanna) shoots and kills a man while he walks through a busy train station. She flees before a flashback to the previous day, when she rides her bike, meets friends and is alone in a bedroom at dusk. At a nightclub the protagonist dances and flirts with another club-goer, who then attacks her when she leaves the club. Disheveled, the woman cries in the street after an implied [[sexual assault]], and the video ends as she runs home to grab a gun hidden in a dresser drawer.<ref name="Man Down Video Synopsis">{{cite web|last=Dinh|first=James|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1664864/rihanna-man-down-video/|title=Rihanna Pulls The Trigger In 'Man Down' Video|work=MTV News|date=May 31, 2011|accessdate=May 31, 2011}}</ref>
===Analysis and reception=== Janell Hobson analysed the imagery presented in the video for "Man Down" in her book ''Body as Evidence: Mediating Race, Globalizing Gender'', which "challenges postmodernist dismissals of identity politics and the delusional belief that the Millennial era reflects a 'postracial' and 'postfeminist' world."<ref name="Hobson">{{cite book |last=Hobson |first=Janell |date=October 18, 2012 |title=Body as Evidence: Mediating Race, Globalizing Gender |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pMpKLdkpnp8C&pg=PA82&dq=%22rihanna%22+%22man+down%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDAQ6AEwBGoVChMI3ZeHy-yFyAIVSpWUCh0sBw6w#v=onepage&q=%22rihanna%22%20%22man%20down%22&f=false |location= |publisher= [[SUNY Press]]|page=82 |isbn=1438444001}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Body-Evidence-Mediating-Globalizing-Gender/dp/1438444001|title=Body as Evidence: Mediating Race, Globalizing Gender Paperback – 18 Oct 2012|work=''[[Amazon.com]]''|date=October 12, 2012|accessdate=September 20, 2015}}</ref> In the chapter titled "Disclosures: Black Women's Resistance to Sexual Violence", Hobson explores how black women have "found the courage" to speak out about sexual violence, protest against it and not remain a silent victim.<ref name="Hobson"/> She recalled Rihanna's interview for ''[[20/20 (U.S. TV series)|20/20]]'' with [[Diane Sawyer]], which aired on November 6, 2009.<ref name="Hobson"/> Having remained silent about her altercation with Brown on the evening of the Grammy Party in February that year, whereby Brown assaulted her, Rihanna decided to speak about it for the first time.<ref name="Hobson"/> The author noted how Sawyer decided to approach the interview by presenting the couples relationship and assault case as an "anomaly" and accused Rihanna of "projecting a 'fake' imagery of strong black woman", rather than presenting her another domestic violence victim not only in the United States, but in the world.<ref name="Hobson"/> "I ''am'' strong," Rihanna responded.<ref name="Hobson"/> Hobson wrote that from then on, the singer decided to project an image of "hardcore masculinity and dominatrix-type femininity in her music trajectory".<ref name="Hobson"/>
Subsequently, several of Rihanna's songs and music videos have courted controversy for their violent themes, which Hobson attributes to the leaking of a photo showing the singers "battered face" on the evening of the assault by [[TMZ]] which circulated the internet without the permission of Rihanna.<ref name="Hobson"/> Hobson writes: "Because of this, Rihanna has had to wrest back control of the 'victim' image foisted on her, and she in turn has challenged us rhetorically and visually to question and examine the power, danger, and violences that shape our relationships."<ref name="Hobson"/> She continued to highlight the music videos for "[[Russian Roulette (Rihanna song)|Russian Roulette]]", "[[Hard (Rihanna song)|Hard]]", "[[We Found Love]]", "[[Love the Way You Lie]]" with [[Eminem]] which documents domestic violence, and "[[S&M (song)|S&M]]", which contains references to [[Bondage (BDSM)|bondage]] and [[Sexual fetishism|fetishism]] and is, in part, Rihanna's response to disparaging critics, as examples.<ref name="Hobson"/> At one point in the video for "S&M", Rihanna is literally tied up as a victim.<ref name="Hobson"/>
However, Hobson noted that Rihanna "rejects the victim stance" in the video for "Man Down", and elucidated that she played the role of a rape survivor who shot her attacker.<ref name="Hobson"/> She attributed the location of shooting the video in Jamaica as significant, due to how the image of a gun proliferated during 1990s Jamaican [[dance hall]]'s to "express female rage".<ref name="Hobson"/> The prologue depicts Rihanna as a "dark-hooded" ''[[femme fatale]]'' whereby the narrative explains her motives for murder and provokes the spectator to sympathize with her because she danced in a provocative manner with a man in a club, which Hobson suggests is "somehow deserving of rape".<ref name="Hobson"/> She continued to explain that Rihanna is inviting the audience to consider what justice means by "pointing both a literal and lyrical gun at the issue".<ref name="Hobson"/> Hobson concluded that Rihanna is protecting her vulnerability and countering the image of the abused black woman who is looked at unsympathetically in society.<ref name="Hobson"/>
Beck Bain of [[Idolator (website)|Idolator]] described the video as "visually stunning",<ref>{{cite web|last=Bain|first=becky|url=http://www.idolator.com/5883402/rihanna-shoots-to-kill-in-her-man-down-video|title=Rihanna Shoots To Kill In Her 'Man Down' Video|work=''[[Idolator (website)|Idolator]]''|date=May 31, 2015|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref> while ''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]'' writer Lee Ann labelled it as "shocking".<ref name="Mothers Against Violence"/> Co-writer of "Man Down" Theron Thomas felt that the video was very theatrical and that Rihanna played her role "perfectly".<ref name="NME Rock City Interview"/> He continued to say that had the video been a lyric-by-lyric representation, the narrative would have been more "graphic".<ref name="NME Rock City Interview"/>
===Controversy=== [[File:GabrielleUnionFeb09 cropped.jpg|thumb|left|Actress [[Gabrielle Union]] ''(pictured)'', a rape victim, said that she could relate to the music video's storyline.|alt=A woman with her head tiled up slightly, smiling.]] The [[Parents Television Council]] (PTC) criticized Rihanna for her portrayal of "cold, calculated execution of murder" in the music video, and argued that murdering a rapist as socially-acceptable justice is impermissible. The group disagreed with Rihanna's rationale for the storyline: that the video has "a very strong underlying message [for] girls" like Rihanna.<ref name="Rap Up PTC">{{cite news|url=http://www.rap-up.com/2011/06/01/rihanna-draws-fire-from-parents-advocacy-group-for-man-down-video/#more-86812|title=Rihanna's 'Man Down' Video Draws Fire from Parents Advocacy Group|work=Rap-Up|date=June 1, 2011|accessdate=June 2, 2015}}</ref> According to the PTC and Industry Ears, if Chris Brown murdered a woman in a video that premiered on BET "the world would stop" and Rihanna should not have been allowed to release her clip.<ref name="Mothers Against Violence"/><ref name="Rap Up PTC"/> The week before the council's statement about the video it had objected to Rihanna and [[Britney Spears]]' performance of the "[[S&M (song)|S&M]]" remix at the [[2011 Billboard Music Awards|''Billboard'' Music Awards]], having called it a "profanity-laced, S&M sex show on prime-time broadcast television".<ref>{{cite web|last=Corner|first=Lewis|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a321473/rihanna-britney-spears-sm-sex-show-slammed.html#~pergfBqC1E1koz|title=Rihanna, Britney Spears 'S&M' 'sex show' slammed|work=Digital Spy|date=May 25, 2011|accessdate=June 2, 2015}}</ref>
After the PTC's statement, Julianne Escobedo Shepherd of [[AlterNet]] wrote that the group seemed to employ a [[double standard]]; it had not condemned [[Kanye West]]'s music video for "[[Monster (Kanye West song)#Music video|Monster]]", in which dead women hang from ceilings and West holds a severed head. Shepard added that Eminem and Rihanna's video for "Love the Way You Lie" had not been criticized, despite the fact that she felt that it "glorified and romanticized" [[domestic violence]].<ref name="Shepard">{{cite web|last=Shepherd|first=Julianne Escobedo|url=http://www.alternet.org/story/151326/watchdogs,_outraged_over_rihanna%27s_new_video,_give_kanye%27s_misogyny_a_pass/?page=entire|title=Watchdogs, Outraged Over Rihanna's New Video, Give Kanye's Misogyny a Pass|work=[[AlterNet]]|date=June 16, 2011|accessdate=June 2, 2015}}</ref> A Mothers Against Violence spokesperson criticised Rihanna for failing to present a solution, rather than encouraging the vulnerable youth, for which rape is a reality for many people.<ref name="Mothers Against Violence">{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Ann|url=http://metro.co.uk/2011/06/02/rihannas-man-down-video-should-be-banned-say-us-pressure-groups-36442/|title=Rihanna’s Man Down video should be banned, say US pressure groups|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|date=June 2, 2011|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref> Director Anthony Mandler addressed the controversy in an interview for ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', saying that the visual evoked the reaction he intended and that it highlighted an issue still taboo in modern society.<ref name="Mandler Hollywood Reporter">{{cite news|last=Kits|first=Boris|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/rihannas-man-down-music-video-195736|title=Rihanna's 'Man Down' Music Video Director Defends Controversial Violence (Exclusive)|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=June 8, 2011|accessdate=June 2, 2015}}</ref> He recalled growing up in an era in which artists such as [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] released controversial music videos, and noted that contemporary videos no longer tackle taboo subjects as frequently.<ref name="Mandler Hollywood Reporter"/>
Rihanna responded to the PTC's criticism on Twitter, and said that parents should not expect her to parent their children and that "touchy subject matters" should not be hidden from children otherwise they will not learn how to adapt in society, and that it empowers abusers even more because children are embarrassed to talk about rape.<ref name="DS Video 1"/><ref name="Hollywood Report Explain"/> The singer continued to state that "the industry isn't 'Parent's 'R Us{{' "}} and that singers "have the freedom to create art".<ref name="DS Video 1">{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a322851/rihanna-man-down-murder-video-is-the-real-world.html|title=Rihanna: 'Man Down murder video is the real world' – Music News |work=Digital Spy|date=June 2, 2011|accessdate=June 2, 2015}}</ref> In an interview for ''BET'', Rihanna further explain why rape was used as the vehicle to push the story forward in the video despite the lyrics not mentioning rape, saying "Making that into a mini-movie or video, we needed to go back to why it happened. Obviously she's not a cold-blooded killer. It had to be something so offensive. And we decided to home in on a very serious matter that people are afraid to address, especially if you've been victimized in this scenario."<ref name="Hollywood Report Explain">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/rihanna-explains-controversial-man-down-194425|title=Rihanna Explains Controversial 'Man Down' Video on BET's '106 & Park' (Video)|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=June 2, 2011|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref> Rihanna added that the character is remorseful for her actions.<ref name="Hollywood Report Explain"/>
Actress and women's-health advocate [[Gabrielle Union]], a rape victim, voiced support for the video on Twitter. Union called it "brave" and, although she did not agree with the [[eye for an eye]] sentiment, she could relate to the situation. Union said that every rape victim or survivor is a unique situation, and that they all have an idea of how justice should be served. She admitted that she tried to shoot her rapist, but missed, and that she has since realised that committing murder as a form of justice for herself would not have made the situation better. She continued to say that while it is "understandable" to desire to kill a rapist, unless it is in [[self-defense]] then it is not advisable.<ref name="Shepard"/>
==Live performances and covers== Rihanna has included "Man Down" on the set lists of several concerts and tours, including the 2011 [[Loud Tour]],<ref name="video">{{cite video | people=|year=2012|title=Loud Tour Live at the O2| medium=DVD, Blu-ray Disc|work=''SRP, [[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]]''}}</ref> [[Radio 1's Big Weekend#2012|BBC Radio 1's Hackney Weekend]] on May 24, 2012<ref name="Hackney">{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/events/e9wmxj/acts/adjc6q#p00wgd44|title=Rihanna – Set list|work=BBC|date=June 24, 2012|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> and the 2013 [[Diamonds World Tour]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/music/ci_22974451/setlist-rihanna-san-jose|title=Setlist: Rihanna in San Jose|work=[[Mercury News]]|last=Harrington|first=Jim|date=April 6, 2013|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> For the Loud Tour, Rihanna performed the song on "a levitating, rotating platform, a conveyer belt and graffiti-laden car shell."<ref>{{cite web|last=Stevenson|first=Jane|url=http://www.torontosun.com/2011/06/07/rihanna-is-loud-sexy-and-larger-than-life|title=Rihanna is loud, sexy and larger than life|work=[[Toronto Sun]]|date=June 7, 2011|accessdate=September 7, 2015}}</ref> Although Kitty Empire described "Man Down" as "terrific", the critic felt let down by the "baffling lack of creativity" from Rihanna's production team for the stage set up during Rihanna's performance. She wrote that she did not understand why a truck [[Hood (vehicle)|bonnet]] was in the middle of the stage.<ref name="Context"/> Maza praised the tracks placement on the set-list. "Man Down" was performed as the fourth song on the Loud Tour, following its opener "[[Only Girl (In the World)]]", "[[Disturbia (song)|Disturbia]]" and "[[Shut Up and Drive (Rihanna song)|Shut Up and Drive]]". Maza noted that the tempo of "Man Down" should have "slowed down the momentum she'd accumulated until then but that was instead an ideal marriage of production and performance." Instead, the red lights on the stage played up the "ominous" tone of the song as it gradually increased its tempo to the point whereby the end of the song was on the verge of sounding like an [[incantation]].<ref name="Baltimore">{{cite web|last=Maza|first=Erik|url=http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/midnight_sun/blog/2011/06/rihanna_review_june_four.html|title=Rihanna at 1st Mariner Arena, first stop of Loud Tour|work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|date=June 6, 2011|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref>
For the Diamonds World Tour, Rihanna performed "Man Down" in a Caribbean-theme section of the show, which also included "[[You da One]]", "[[No Love Allowed]]", "[[What's My Name? (Rihanna song)|What's My Name?]]" and "[[Rude Boy (Rihanna song)|Rude Boy]]".<ref name="Oakland">{{cite web|last=Graff|first=Gary|url=http://www.theoaklandpress.com/general-news/20130322/concert-review-rihannas-diamonds-show-doesnt-shine-at-joe-louis-arena|title=Concert Review: Rihanna's Diamonds show doesn't shine at Joe Louis Arena|work=[[The Oakland Press]]|date=March 22, 2013|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref> <ref name="MEN">{{cite web|last=Fitzpatrick |first=Katie |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/music/review-rihanna-at-manchester-arena-4307497 |title=Review: Rihanna at Manchester Arena |work=[[Manchester Evening News]] |date=June 13, 2013 |accessdate=September 21, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303223836/http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/music/review-rihanna-at-manchester-arena-4307497 |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |df= }}</ref> James Lachno of ''The Telegraph'' highlight the Caribbean-themed section as the show's highlight.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lachno|first=James|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/live-music-reviews/10112132/Rihanna-Millennium-Stadium-Cardiff-review.html|title=Rihanna, Millennium Stadium, Cardiff, review|work=The Telegraph|date=June 11, 2013|accessdate=September 21, 2015}}</ref> ''[[Manchester Evening News]]'' writer Katie Fitzpatrick commented that Rihanna transported the audience to the Caribbean with a "grinding groove".<ref name="MEN"/> However, Gary Graff of ''[[The Oakland Press]]'' was disappointed with the lack of variety in the section, writing that it was "addled by a sonic sameness, even with [[Nuno Bettencourt]] of [[Extreme (band)|Extreme]], whose guitar was buried in the bass-heavy mix, playing some intriguing licks and accents".<ref name="Oakland"/>
British singer and songwriter Leona Lewis performed a mashup of "Man Down" with her 2008 single "[[Better in Time]]" at [[BBC Radio 1]]'s [[Live Lounge]] in June 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Daw|first=Robbie|url=http://www.idolator.com/5872112/leona-lewis-rihanna-man-down-live-lounge|title=Leona Lewis Mashes Up 'Better In Time' With Rihanna’s 'Man Down'|work=Idolator|date=June 25, 2011|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|title=Radio 1 to stage its biggest ever live music event on Hackney Marshes|work=BBC|date=May 23, 2011|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2011/05_may/23/hackney.shtml|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> She also included the mashup on the set list of her 2013 [[Glassheart Tour]].<ref name="Digispy Glassheart Setlist">{{cite web|last=Corner|first=Lewis|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a473838/leona-lewis-begins-glassheart-tour-in-germany-pictures.html|title=Leona Lewis begins 'Glassheart' tour in Germany – pictures|work=Digital Spy|date=April 17, 2013|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> Her rendition received a mixed response from critics. Katherine Hollisey-McLean of the ''Worthing Herald'' complimented the fusion of "Better in Time" with reggae beats,<ref name="Brighton review">{{cite web|last=Hollisey |first=Katherine |url=http://www.worthingherald.co.uk/what-s-on/review-leona-lewis-at-the-brighton-centre-1-5054884 |title=Review: Leona Lewis at the Brighton Centre – What's On |work=Worthing Herald |accessdate=May 7, 2013}}</ref> while ''The Guardian''{{'}}s Malcolm Jack thought the performance was "cringey" and called Lewis a "reasonably priced Rihanna".<ref name="Guardian Review">{{cite news|author=Malcolm Jack |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/apr/28/leona-lewis-review|title=Leona Lewis – review|work=The Guardian |date=April 28, 2013|accessdate=April 30, 2015}}</ref> {{Clear}}
