page.title: Media coverage of the Syrian Civil War

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Outdated as of | 2015}} <!--NOTNEWS and this is not a weblog as this article clearly seems to demonstrate a "list of" tidbits and TRIVIA--> [[File:Работа журналистов на авиабазе «Хмеймим» в Сирии (10).jpg|300px|thumb|Journalists interviewing Russian General Igor Konashenkov ([[:ru:Конашенков, Игорь Евгеньевич|ru:И́горь Конаше́нков]]) at [[Bassel Al-Assad International Airport]] during the [[Russian military intervention in the Syrian Civil War]]]]
Since the start of the [[Syrian Civil War]], all sides have used [[social media]] to try to discredit their opponents by using negative terms such as 'Syrian regime', 'armed gangs/terrorists', 'Syrian government/US State Department propaganda', 'biased', 'US/Western/foreign involvement'.{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} According to the [[Stockholm International Peace Research Institute]], given the complexity of the Syrian conflict, media bias in reporting remains a key challenge, plaguing the collection of useful data and misinforming researchers and policymakers regarding the actual events taking place.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sipriyearbook.org/view/9780198712596/sipri-9780198712596-chapter-2-div1-2.xml# |title=I. Measuring conflict incidence in Syria|publisher=Sipri Yearbook|accessdate=28 August 2015}}</ref>
==Internet activists==
===Social media=== As in the revolutions in Tunisia and Egypt, the Internet played a major role in the organization and coverage of the protests/armed-uprising. As of 2011 the largest Facebook page in support of the Syrian uprising was '''"The Syrian Revolution 2011"''', which claimed more than 383,000 followers. The page, co-founded by [[Fida al-Sayed]], reports on news related to the uprising and provides general guidelines for protests.<ref>{{Facebook Page|id=Syrian Revolution}}</ref>
As of 2015 the largest Facebook page in support of the Syrian President Bashar-al-Assad has more than 2,958,595 followers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/almayadeen.tv |title=قناة الميادين - Al Mayadeen Tv - Facebook |work=Facebook |accessdate=28 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150713073027/https://www.facebook.com/almayadeen.tv |archivedate=13 July 2015 }}</ref>
*[[Bana Alabed]], a 2016 Twitter account of unclear provenance about a child purportedly tweeting in English from Aleppo as the city was being destroyed.<ref name=nyt-20161207>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/07/world/middleeast/aleppo-twitter-girl-syria.html |title=Girl Posting to Twitter From Aleppo Gains Sympathy, but Doubts Follow |author1=Rick Gladstone |author2=Megan Specia |author3=Sydney Ember |newspaper=The New York Times |date=7 December 2016 |accessdate=8 December 2016}}</ref>
===Mobiles=== Since international news media was banned in Syria, the main source of second-hand information/dis-information was private videos usually taken by shaky mobile phone cameras and uploaded to YouTube. Such videos were difficult to verify independently, and several TV stations showed older footage from Iraq and Lebanon, which was claimed to have been filmed in Syria.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/mediawatch/transcripts/s3218415.htm |title=Media Watch: Beware the 'trusted' source|date=16 May 2011|work=ABC |location=Australia|accessdate=13 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://avisen.dk/gigantisk-dr-bommert-uden-konsekvenser_146651.aspx |title=Gigantisk DR-bommert uden konsekvenser – |work=Avisen.dk |date=18 May 2011 |accessdate=13 November 2011}}</ref> Twitter accounts have also been used to spread news and opinions about the conflict, using pictures from mobile phones. For example, pro Assad [[Rana Harbi]] from [[Lebanon]]<ref>https://twitter.com/RanaHarbi?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor</ref> is one of the most popular persons{{cn|date=October 2018}} using tweets to inform about the conflict development (using pictures from mobile phones).
==Visual media==
Between January 2012 and September 2013, over a million videos documenting the war have been uploaded, and they have received hundreds of millions of views.<ref>{{cite news|title=Syria's War Viewed Almost in Real Time|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887324492604579083112566791956|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=27 September 2013}}</ref> ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' states that the "unprecedented confluence of two technologies—cellphone cams and social media—has produced, via the instant upload, a new phenomenon: the YouTube war." ''The New York Times'' states that online videos have "allowed a widening war to be documented like no other."<ref>{{cite news|title=Watching Syria's War|url=http://projects.nytimes.com/watching-syrias-war|accessdate=29 September 2013|newspaper=NYT}}</ref>
Prominent videos include the rebel commander [[Abu Sakkar]] cutting organs from the dead body of a Syrian soldier and putting one of them in his mouth, "as if he is taking a bite out of it". He called rebels to follow his example and terrorize the [[Alawite]] sect, which mostly backs Assad.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2013/05/13/syria-brigade-fighting-homs-implicated-atrocities |title=Syria: Brigade Fighting in Homs Implicated in Atrocities|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]|date=13 May 2013|accessdate=15 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-22519770|title=Outrage at Syrian rebel shown 'eating soldier's heart'|publisher=BBC|date=14 May 2013|accessdate=15 May 2014}}</ref>
==Propaganda== Syria is ranked the third most repressive country in the world in terms of press freedom by the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cpj.org/reports/2012/05/10-most-censored-countries.php |title=10 Most Censored Countries |work=Committee to Protect Journalists |date=2 May 2012 |accessdate=14 August 2012}}</ref> and the 4th most repressive by [[Reporters Without Borders]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2011-2012,1043.html |title=Press Freedom Index 2011-2012 |work=Reporters Without Borders |date= |accessdate=14 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303230901/http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2011-2012%2C1043.html |archivedate=3 March 2016 |df= }}</ref>
It has been rumoured that [[Syrian Arab News Agency]] (SANA) television interviews sometimes use government supporters 'disguised as locals' who stand near sites of destruction and claim that they were caused by rebel fighters.<ref name="Propaganda"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Chulov|first=Martin|title=Syrian regime TV reporter defects|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jul/02/syrian-regime-tv-reporter-defects|newspaper=The Guardian|date=3 July 2012|location=London}}</ref>
The Lebanese newspaper ''[[As-Safir]]'' cited outtakes of interviews showing that the channel's staff coached Syrian eyewitnesses and fabricated reports of oppression by Syria's government. It refers to leaked internal e-mails suggest that [[Al Jazeera]] has become subordinated to the Qatari emir's assertive foreign policy, which supports Syria's rebels and advocates military intervention in the country.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-04-09/al-jazeera-gets-rap-as-qatar-mouthpiece.html | work=Bloomberg | title=Al-Jazeera Gets Rap as Qatar Mouthpiece}}</ref>
In March 2012, Al Jazeera correspondents [[Ali Hashim]] and two others resigned from their jobs because of objections over the reporting on the conflict. They reported that Al Jazeera paid $50,000 for smuggling phones and satellite communication tools to Syria's rebels. Hashim concluded, "The channel was taking a certain stance. It was meddling with each and every detail of reports on the Syrian revolution."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rt.com/news/al-jazeera-rebels-phones-lebanon-281/ |title=Ex-employee: Al Jazeera provided Syrian rebels with satphones — RT News |publisher=Rt.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-13}}</ref>{{better source|RT is not RS|date=October 2018}}
[[Ahmad Ibrahim (journalist)|Ahmad Ibrahim]], who is in charge of the Al Jazeera's coverage on Syria, is the brother of a leading member of the opposition [[Syrian National Council]].{{fact|date=October 2018}} Al Jazeera reportedly put pressure on its journalists to use the term "martyr" for slain Syrian rebels, but not pro-government forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/node/4525/ |title=Syria's Electronic Warriors Hit Al Jazeera |publisher=Al Akhbar English |date=2012-02-24 |accessdate=2014-08-13}}</ref>
In January 2013, a former News Editor at Al Jazeera, who was from Syria, and had been at Al Jazeera for "nearly a decade" was fired without cause given, but in an interview stated their belief that it was linked to his/her resistance of ongoing strong pressure to conform to biased coverage of the Syrian civil war. The former Editor stated that the Muslim Brotherhood was "controlling the Syrian file at Al-Jazeera" with both organizations biasing news coverage in favour of the Brotherhood ousting the Syrian government of Assad by force and warning the then-editor "the majority [in Syria] is with the Muslim Brotherhood and [taking power] is within our grasp" so "thank your god if you get a pardon when we become the government." The source named the names of several other former employees who resigned in protest, including director of the Berlin bureau [[Aktham Sleiman]], a Syrian, "who was, at the beginning, with the [Syrian] opposition" but resisted what the interviewee terms the "lies and despicable [political and ethnic] sectarianism" and concluded that "Al-Jazeera has lied and is still lying" about Syria and in favour of armed overthrow and of the Muslim Brotherhood.<ref>[http://axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/Article_65277.shtml An exclusive interview with a news editor of Al-Jazeera Channel] at AxisOfLogin</ref><ref>[http://www.filmyboxoffice.com/news/interview-with-a-former-journalist-in-the-qatari-al-jazeera.html An exclusive interview with a news editor of Al-Jazeera Channel] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130914144606/http://www.filmyboxoffice.com/news/interview-with-a-former-journalist-in-the-qatari-al-jazeera.html |date=14 September 2013 }} at FilmBoxOffice</ref>{{better source|a blog and a dead link|date=October 2018}}
Propaganda has been used by the Syrian government since the beginning of the conflict.<ref name="Propaganda">{{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/09/world/meast/syria-propagandist-defects/ |title=Defecting Syrian propagandist says his job was 'to fabricate' | date=9 October 2012 | accessdate=14 October 2012|publisher=CNN}}</ref> The [[Syrian Arab News Agency]] (SANA), the official government news agency, often refers to the FSA and ISIS as "armed gangs" or "terrorists" - while other media sources maintain that only part of the opposition are 'extremists'.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/09/07/world/meast/syria-civil-war/index.html |publisher=CNN |title=State TV reports 6 dead in Damascus 'terrorist' blast |date=8 September 2012 |accessdate=14 October 2012}}</ref> President Assad has characterized the opposition as armed terrorist groups with Islamist ''"[[takfiri]]"'' extremist motives, portraying himself as the last guarantee for a secular government form.<ref name=127dead>{{cite news |title=Opposition: 127 dead as Syrian forces target civilians |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2012-04-07/middleeast/world_meast_syria-unrest_1_homs-and-hama-syrian-observatory-network-of-opposition-activists |publisher=CNN |date=7 April 2012 |accessdate=23 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221022240/http://www.cnn.com/2012/04/07/world/meast/syria-unrest/index.html |archivedate=21 February 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Syrian public school instructors teach students that the conflict is a foreign conspiracy.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EHE6PyiMXgQ| title=Damascus School Struggles to Carry On | date=1 October 2012 | accessdate=14 October 2012|publisher=Voice of America}}</ref>
The [[Minister of Foreign Affairs and Expatriates (Syria)|Syrian foreign ministry]] called the U.S. government's statements in 2012, concerning the danger of the Syrian government using chemical weapons against civilians a myth they invented to launch a campaign against Syria and "a joke",<ref>[http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2012/Oct-01/189775-syria-accuses-us-of-chemical-weapons-propaganda.ashx#axzz2GlZHI25C Syria accuses U.S. of chemical weapons propaganda]. ''The Daily Star'' (Lebanon), 1 October 2012. Retrieved 20 April 2014.</ref> thus accusing the U.S. of propaganda on that subject; which accusation and denial of above-mentioned danger, 'are in turn of course again examples of propaganda'.
In 2016, it was revealed through [[emails of Hillary Clinton]] that [[Google]] and Al-Jazeera planned to encourage defections from the Syrian government, through various internet tools that disseminate information.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3503000/Hillary-Clinton-s-emails-reveal-Google-wanted-overthrow-Assad-map-tool.html Daily Mail]</ref>{{better source|DM is not RS|date=October 2018}}
===Hoaxes=== Both sides have been distributing on social media videos and photos of violence, while falsely claiming that the atrocities had been committed by the opposition: later it turned out to be footage from conflicts in other countries.<ref>{{cite web|author=Military & Defense Contributors |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/disturbing-fake-videos-are-making-the-rounds-in-syria-2012-11 |title=Disturbing Fake Videos Are Making The Rounds in Syria |publisher=Business Insider |date=13 November 2012 |accessdate=8 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/middle-east/syria/121109/fake-syria-videos-images|title=The most disturbing fake videos making the rounds in Syria|author=Tracey Shelton|work=GlobalPost|accessdate=28 August 2015}}</ref>
Examples:
* [[A Gay Girl In Damascus]], a 2011 blog written by an American posing as a gay girl in Damascus.<ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/style/a-gay-girl-in-damascus-comes-clean/2011/06/12/AGkyH0RH_story.html Washington Post]</ref> *"Syrian Hero Boy", a 2015 viral video showing a Syrian boy rescuing a girl under gunfire, watched online by millions of viewers, was faked by a Norwegian film crew, according to its director. Posted on YouTube, the "''Syrian Hero Boy''" video<ref>{{cite web |title=SYRIA! SYRIAN HERO BOY rescue girl in shootout. SEE THIS!! الصبي السوري البطل |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IWew2rR68WY |website=YouTube |publisher=alaa hassen |date=2014-11-04 |accessdate=2016-08-17}} from 00m00s to 1m06s</ref> was shot on location in Malta in the summer of 2014 with professional actors, directed by 34-year-old Norwegian [[Lars Klevberg]], who hoped to provoke debates about media distortion and context children in war zones.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-30057401|title=#BBCTrending: Syrian 'hero boy' video faked by Norwegian director - BBC News|work=BBC News|accessdate=28 August 2015}}</ref> *In 2011, the 18 year old [[Zainab Alhusni]] was claimed to have been taken in Syrian custody and later killed and mutilated, due to her brother being an activist. Her family held a funeral, but she later turned out to be alive, and had run away from home because her brothers beat her.<ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2011/10/05/world/meast/syria-woman-alive/ CNN}</ref>
== Attacks on journalists == {{See also|List of journalists killed during the Syrian Civil War}} It has been maintained that, by October 2012, 'more than hundred professional or citizen journalists' had reportedly died in the [[Syrian Civil War]]. According to the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]], 13 journalists were killed in work-related incidents during the first eighteen months of the uprising.<ref>{{cite web |title= Journalists Killed in Syria since 1992 |url= http://www.cpj.org/killed/mideast/syria/ |publisher= Committee to Protect Journalists |accessdate=19 July 2012}} [[Nota bene|N.B.]] According to the organisation, no journalists were killed in Syria between 1992 and the start of the uprising.</ref> During the same period, [[Reporters Without Borders]] said a total of 33 journalists were killed.<ref>{{cite web |title= Thirty-Three Professional and Citizen Journalists Killed since March 2011 |url= http://en.rsf.org/syrie-thirty-three-professional-and-07-07-2012,42982.html |publisher= Reporters Without Borders |accessdate=19 July 2012}}</ref> Examples are [[Marie Colvin]] who was killed by an explosion during the battle of Homs,<ref>{{cite web |last= Wardrop |first= Murray |date= 22 February 2012 |title= Syria: ''Sunday Times'' journalist Marie Colvin 'killed in Homs' |url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/9097762/Syria-Sunday-Times-journalist-Marie-Colvin-killed-in-Homs.html |publisher= telegraph.co.uk |accessdate=19 July 2012}}</ref> but at least one, French journalist [[Gilles Jacquier]], was killed by rebel mortar fire.<ref>{{cite web |last= Malbrunot |first= Georges |date= 17 July 2012 |title= Jacquier: l'enquête française pointe les rebelles syriens |trans-title= Jacquier: French investigation points to Syrian rebels |url= http://www.lefigaro.fr/international/2012/07/17/01003-20120717ARTFIG00525-jacquier-l-enquete-francaise-pointe-les-rebelles-syriens.php|language=French|publisher= [[Le Figaro|LeFigaro.fr]] |accessdate=19 July 2012}}</ref>
Except for those hand-picked by the government, journalists have been banned from reporting in Syria. Those who have entered the country regardless have been targeted. Within a month of the protests taking off, at least seven local and international journalists were detained, and at least one of them was beaten.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.hrw.org/news/2011/04/15/syria-rampant-torture-protesters |title= Syria: Rampant Torture of Protesters |publisher= HRW |date= 16 April 2011 |accessdate=30 June 2012}}</ref> 'Citizen journalist' Mohammed Hairiri was arrested in April 2012, tortured in prison, and sentenced to death in May 2012 for giving an interview for Al Jazeera.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/syria-citizen-journalist-sentenced-to-18-05-2012,42641.html |title=Citizen journalist sentenced to death for Al-Jazeera interview - Reporters Without Borders |publisher=En.rsf.org |date= |accessdate=6 July 2012}}</ref> Jordanian Salameh Kaileh was tortured and detained in deplorable conditions before being deported.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.amnesty.org/en/news/syria-deported-palestinian-journalist-speaks-out-about-torture-custody-2012-05-17 |title= Syria: Deported Palestinian journalist speaks out about torture in custody |publisher= Amnesty International |date= 17 May 2012 |accessdate=30 June 2012}}</ref>
=== NBC News team kidnapping === {{main|NBC News team kidnapping in Syria}}
On 13 December 2012, [[NBC News]] reporter [[Richard Engel]] and his five crew members, Aziz Akyavaş, Ghazi Balkiz, John Kooistra, Ian Rivers and Ammar Cheikh Omar, were abducted in Syria. Having escaped after five days in captivity, Engel said he believed that a [[Shabiha]] group loyal to [[Bashar al-Assad|al-Assad]] was behind the abduction, and that the crew was freed by the [[Ahrar ash-Sham]] group five days later.<ref>{{citation |author1=[[Brian Stelter]] |author2=Sebnem Arsu |title=Richard Engel of NBC Is Freed in Syria |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/19/business/media/richard-engel-of-nbc-is-released-in-syria.html |date=18 December 2012 |accessdate=8 December 2015}}</ref> Engel's account was however challenged from early on.<ref>{{cite web |author=Jamie Dettmer |title=Richard Engel's Kidnapping: A Behind the Scenes Look |work=[[The Daily Beast]] |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/12/22/richard-engel-s-kidnapping-a-behind-the-scenes-look.html |date=22 December 2012 |accessdate=8 December 2015}}</ref> In April 2015, NBC had to revise the kidnapping account, following further investigations by ''[[The New York Times]]'', which suggested that the NBC team "was almost certainly taken by a Sunni criminal element affiliated with the [[Free Syrian Army]]," rather than by a loyalist [[Shia]] group.<ref>{{cite news |author1=Ravi Somaiya |author2=[[C. J. Chivers]] |author3=Karam Shoumali |title=NBC News Alters Account of Correspondent's Kidnapping in Syria |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/16/business/media/nbc-news-alters-account-of-correspondents-kidnapping-in-syria.html |date=15 April 2015 |accessdate=8 December 2015}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Media of Syria]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== {{commons category|Media coverage of the Syrian Civil War}}
*Joseph Daher [https://www.opendemocracy.net/north-africa-west-asia/joseph-daher/syria-uprising-and-media-scene Syria, the uprising and the media scene], ''OpenDemocracy'' 26 October 2017 *James Miller and Matt Sienkiewicz [https://archives.cjr.org/behind_the_news/straight_news_from_the_citizen.php Straight news from the citizens of Syria] ''Columbia Journalism Review'' August 16, 2012
{{2011 Syrian uprising}}
[[Category:Syrian Civil War]] [[Category:Media in Syria]] [[Category:War and the media]] [[Category:Arab Spring and the media|Syrian Civil War]]

revision.comment: Removed [[WP:UNSOURCED]] content tagged with citation needed since 2007.
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Great Sky River|the novel|Great Sky River (novel)}} {{about|mythology related to the Milky Way Galaxy||Milky Way (disambiguation)}} [[Image:MilkyWay behind Tree 2.jpg|thumb]]
There are many myths and legends about the origin of the [[Milky Way]], the crowd of stars that makes a distinctive bright streak across the night sky.
==Mythology among cultures==
===Armenian=== Ancient [[Armenian mythology]] called the Milky Way the "Straw Thief's Way". According to legend, the god [[Vahagn]] stole some straw from the [[Assyria]]n king Barsham and brought it to Armenia during a cold winter. When he fled across the heavens, he spilled some of the straw along the way.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Harutyunyan | first =Hayk | title = The Armenian name of the Milky Way | journal = ArAS News | volume =6 | publisher = Armenian Astronomical Society (ArAS) | date =2003-08-29 | url = http://www.aras.am/ARASNEWS/arasnews06.html | accessdate = 2007-01-05 | format = – <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3AHarutyunyan+intitle%3AThe+Armenian+name+of+the+Milky+Way&as_publication=ArAS+News&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup> |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060429194053/http://www.aras.am/ARASNEWS/arasnews06.html |archivedate = April 29, 2006}}</ref>
===Khoisan=== The [[Khoisan people]] of the [[Kalahari]] desert in southern Africa say that long ago there were no stars and the night was pitch black. A girl, who was lonely and wanted to visit other people, threw the embers from a fire into the sky and created the Milky Way.<ref name="starryskies">{{cite web | last = Miles | first =Mathy A |author2=Peters, Charles F | title =Along the Milky Way | date =2002 | url =http://starryskies.com/Artshtml/dln/10-02/along-the-milky-way.html | accessdate = 2007-01-05 }}</ref>
===Cherokee=== A [[Cherokee mythology|Cherokee folktale]] tells of a dog who stole some [[cornmeal]] and was chased away. He ran away to the north, spilling the cornmeal along the way. The Milky Way is thus called ᎩᎵ ᎤᎵᏒᏍᏓᏅᏱ (''Gili Ulisvsdanvyi'') "The Way the Dog Ran Away".<ref>{{cite web | title = Cherokee legend about the origin of the Milky Way | url = http://www.firstpeople.us/FP-Html-Legends/The-Milky-Way-Cherokee.html | accessdate = 2007-01-05 }}</ref>
===Eastern Asia=== [[File:Guo Xu album dated 1503 (11).jpg|thumb|The creation of the River of Heaven (Milky Way) across the sky, associated with the myth of ''[[The Cowherd and the Weaver Girl]]'']] Peoples in Eastern Asia believed that the hazy band of stars was the "Silvery River" of Heaven ({{zh|c=銀河}}, {{lang-ko|eunha}} and {{lang-ja|ginga}}). In one story, the stars [[Altair]] and [[Vega]] were said to be two lovers who were allowed to meet only once a year on the seventh day of the seventh month, when a flock of [[magpie]]s and [[crow]]s formed a bridge over the galactic river. That day is celebrated as [[Qi Xi]], the ''Seventh Night'' ({{zh|七夕|qī xī}}, {{lang-ko|[[chilseok]]}} and {{lang-ja|tanabata}}).
===Egyptian=== In [[Egyptian mythology]], the Milky Way was considered a pool of cow's milk. The Milky Way was [[:wikt:deify|deified]] as a fertility cow-goddess by the name of [[Bat (goddess)|Bat]] (later on [[Syncretism#Religious syncretism|syncretized]] with the sky goddess [[Hathor]]).
===Finno-Ugric=== Among the Finns, Estonians and related peoples, the Milky Way was and is called "The Pathway of the Birds" ({{lang-fi|Linnunrata}}, {{lang-et|Linnutee}}). The Finns observed that the migratory birds used the galaxy as a guideline to travel south, where they believed ''[[Finnish mythology#The origins and the structure of the world|Lintukoto]]'' (bird home) resided.
In [[Estonian mythology|Estonian folklore]] it is believed that the birds are led by a white bird with the head of a maiden who chases [[birds of prey]] away.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Kuperjanov | first = Andres | title = Names in Estonian folk astronomy – from ‘Bird's Way’ to ‘Milky Way’ | journal = Electronic Journal of Folklore | volume =22 | pages =49–61 | publisher = Folk Belief and Media Group of Estonian Literary Museum |date=December 2002 | url = http://www.folklore.ee/folklore/vol22/milkyway.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2007-01-05 | doi=10.7592/fejf2002.22.milkyway}}</ref> The maiden, the goddess Lindu, was the Queen of the Birds and the daughter of Uko, the King of the Sky. After refusing the suits of the Sun and Moon for being too predictable in their routes and the [[Polaris|Pole Star]] for being fixed, she fell in love with the Light of North for its beauty. They became engaged, but the inconstant Light of North left her soon afterward. The tears of the broken-hearted Lindu fell on her wedding veil, which became the Milky Way when her father brought her to heaven so she could reign by his side and guide the migrating birds, who followed the trail of stars in her veil.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finnishmyth.org/FINNISHMYTH.ORG/Comparative_Mythology.html|title=Comparative Mythology|website=www.finnishmyth.org}}</ref> Only later did scientists indeed confirm this observation; the migratory birds use the Milky Way as a guide to travel to warmer, southern lands during the winter.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Sauer | first = EGF | title = Celestial Rotation and Stellar Orientation in Migratory Warblers | journal = Science | volume =173 | pages =459–461 | date=July 1971 | doi = 10.1126/science.173.3995.459 | url = http://www.sciencemag.org/content/173/3995.toc|bibcode = 1971Sci...173..459S }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last = Mouritsen | last2 = Larsen | title = Migrating songbirds tested in computer-controlled Emlen funnels use stellar cues for a time-independent compass | journal = The Journal of Experimental Biology | volume =204 | pages =3855–3865 | date =2001 | url=http://jeb.biologists.org/content/204/22/3855.full.pdf | format=PDF | accessdate = 2011-11-01 }}</ref>
The name in the [[Indo-European languages|Indo-European]] [[Baltic languages]] has the same meaning ({{lang-lt|Paukščių Takas}}, {{lang-lv|Putnu Ceļš}}).
[[Image:Jacopo Tintoretto - The Origin of the Milky Way - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|right|[[Jacopo Tintoretto]]'s ''[[The Origin of the Milky Way (Tintoretto)|The Origin of the Milky Way]]'']]
===Mesopotamian=== In the [[Babylonia]]n epic poem ''[[Enûma Eliš]]'', the Milky Way is created from the severed tail of the primeval salt water [[dragon]]ess [[Tiamat]], set in the sky by [[Marduk]], the Babylonian [[national god]], after slaying her.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=William P.|title=The Seven Pillars of Creation: The Bible, Science, and the Ecology of Wonder|date=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford, England|isbn=978-0-19-973079-7|page=25|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zce500t8puUC&pg=PA25&dq=Tiamat+Milky+Way&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjMxOnqjeXYAhUNylMKHRT0AZcQ6AEINzAD#v=onepage&q=Tiamat%20Milky%20Way&f=false|ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=MacBeath|first1=Alastair|title=Tiamat's Brood: An Investigation Into the Dragons of Ancient Mesopotamia|date=1999|publisher=Dragon's Head|isbn=9780952438755|page=41|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uobfAAAAMAAJ&q=Tiamat+Milky+Way&dq=Tiamat+Milky+Way&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiGoZr-juXYAhVS61MKHdPDDl8Q6AEIMzAC|ref=harv}}</ref> This story was once thought to have been based on an older [[Sumer]]ian version in which Tiamat is instead slain by [[Enlil]] of [[Nippur]],<ref>{{cite book|last=James|first=E. O.|title=The Worship of the Skygod: A Comparative Study in Semitic and Indo-European Religion|location=London, England|publisher=University of London|series=Jordan Lectures in Comparative religion|date=1963|pages=24, 27f|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Lambert1964">{{cite journal|last=Lambert|first=W. G.|title=Bulletin of the School of Oriental and African Studies|location=London, England|publisher=University of London|volume=27|issue=1|date=1964|pages=157–158|ref=harv}}</ref> but is now though to be purely an invention of Babylonian propagandists with the intention to show Marduk as superior to the Sumerian deities.<ref name="Lambert1964"/> Another myth about [[Labbu]] is similarly interpreted.
===Greek and Roman=== The Greek name for the Milky Way (Γαλαξίας ''Galaxias'') is derived from the Greek word for milk (γάλα, ''gala''). One legend explains how the Milky Way was created by [[Heracles]] when he was a baby.<ref name="starryskies"/> His father, [[Zeus]], was fond of his son, who was born of the mortal woman [[Alcmene]]. He decided to let the infant Heracles suckle on his divine wife [[Hera]]'s milk when she was asleep, an act which would endow the baby with godlike qualities. When Hera woke and realized that she was [[breastfeed]]ing an unknown infant, she pushed him away and the spurting milk became the Milky Way.
Another version of the myth is that [[Heracles]] (Roman [[Hercules]]) was abandoned in the woods by his mortal parents, [[Amphitryon]] and [[Alcmene]]. [[Heracles]], son of [[Zeus]] and [[Alcmene]], was naturally favored by his father, who sent [[Athena]], Greek goddess of wisdom, to retrieve him. [[Athena]], not being so motherly, decided to take him to [[Hera]] to suckle. [[Hera]] agreed to suckle [[Heracles]] As [[Heracles]] drinks the milk, he bites down, and [[Hera]] pushes him away in pain. The milk that squirts out forms the Milky Way.
A story told by the Roman [[Gaius Julius Hyginus|Hyginus]] in the ''[[Poeticon astronomicon]]'' (ultimately based on Greek myth) says that the milk came from the goddess [[Ops]] (Greek [[Rhea (mythology)|Rhea]]), or Opis, the wife of [[Saturn (mythology)|Saturn]] (Greek [[Cronus]]). Saturn swallowed his children to ensure his position as head of the [[List of Greek mythological characters|Pantheon]] and sky god, and so Ops conceived a plan to save her newborn son [[Jupiter (mythology)|Jupiter]] (Greek [[Zeus]]): She wrapped a stone in infant's clothes and gave it to Saturn to swallow. Saturn asked her to nurse the child once more before he swallowed it, and the milk that spurted when she pressed her nipple against the rock eventually became the Milky Way.<ref>{{cite book | last = Hyginus | first = Gaius Julius | authorlink = Gaius Julius Hyginus | title =Poeticon astronomicon | volume =Book 2 | chapter =Chapter 43 | url =http://www.theoi.com/Text/HyginusAstronomica2.html#43 | nopp = true}}</ref>
===Hindu=== In the [[Hindu mythology|Hindu]] collection of stories called [[Bhagavata Purana]], all the visible stars and planets moving through space are likened to a dolphin that swims through the water, and the heavens are called ''śiśumãra cakra'', the dolphin disc. The Milky Way forms the [[abdomen]] of the dolphin and is called ''Akasaganga'' which means "The [[Ganges River]] of the Sky".<ref>{{cite book | translator = Prabhupâda | title =Bhagavata purana | pages =Canto 5 | chapter =Chapter 23 | url =http://srimadbhagavatam.org/canto5/Canto5-Sanskrit/chapter23.html | nopp = true }}</ref>
According to Hindu mythology, [[Vishnu]] lies meditating on [[Shesha]] with his consort [[Lakshmi]], in the Kshira Sagara (Sea of Milk).
===Irish=== [[File:Toormore Altar Wedge Tomb and Milkyway.jpg|thumb|[[Altar Wedge Tomb]] (c. 2500–2000 BC), Ireland, under the Milky Way.]] In [[Irish mythology]], the main name of the Milky Way was ''Bealach na Bó Finne'' — Way of the White Cow. It was regarded as a heavenly reflection of the sacred [[River Boyne]], which is described as "the Great Silver Yoke" and the "White Marrow of [[Fedlimid mac Daill|Fedlimid]]," names which could equally apply to the Milky Way. (''Mór-Chuing Argait'', ''Smir Find Fedlimthi'').<ref>http://theses.univ-lyon2.fr/documents/getpart.php?id=lyon2.2009.beck_n&part=159207</ref>
Other names include: *''Ceann Síne'' — "chief chain"<ref>https://books.google.ie/books?id=HI5yXNhbebYC&printsec=frontcover&dq="Ceann+Síne"&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjeq_3v8N_bAhVSFMAKHVLEBMoQ6AEILTAB</ref> *''Síog na Spéire'' — "stripe of the sky"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://corpas.ria.ie/index.php?fsg_function=3&fsg_id=2756|title=Cartlann Téacsanna|website=corpas.ria.ie}}</ref> *''Earball na Lárach Báine'' — the White Mare's Tail. The [[Láir Bhán]] (white mare) is believed to a relic of a sovereignty goddess, and processions featuring a white [[hobby horse]] formerly took place in [[County Kerry]] around [[Samhain]] (Hallowe'en).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bestow-you-forskolin.com/forskolin_int/?a=389910&netaff=103573&click_id=06_26972001_7c94d945-6287-4c36-8b2e-36a889a0c758&subid1=319573&netid=2&ver=new&geo=intl|title=Forskolin Slim|website=bestow-you-forskolin.com}}</ref> *''Claí Mór na Réaltaí'' — "Great Ditch/Fence of the Stars"<ref>https://books.google.ie/books?id=Hgg-DgAAQBAJ&pg=PT77&lpg=PT77&dq="Claí+Mór+na+Réaltaí"&source=bl&ots=C-qWcUvhVo&sig=wwttWhH52wn8exV-SmNkb-9rOb4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwix7v6P8t_bAhUrJMAKHWIKA6sQ6AEITTAH#v=onepage&q="Claí%20Mór%20na%20Réaltaí"&f=false</ref> *''Sgríob Chlann Uisnich'' — "Track of the [[The Exile of the Sons of Uisnech|children of Uisneach]]."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.mythicalireland.com/2016/10/the-milky-way-in-irish-mythology-and_10.html|title=The Milky Way in Irish mythology and folklore|website=blog.mythicalireland.com}}</ref> This name derives from a legend: after the sons of Uisneach fell in battle, [[Deirdre]] threw herself into their grave. Angered, the king [[Conchobar mac Nessa]] exhumed the bodies and buried them separately, but a tree grew from each grave and the branches entwined. Again he had them dug up and buried on opposite sides of a lake; but then the great cluster of stars appeared across the sky, connecting the two graves.<ref>http://capebretonsmagazine.com/modules/publisher/item.php?itemid=706</ref>
===Hungarian=== In [[Hungary|Hungarian]] mythology, Csaba, the mythical son of [[Attila the Hun]] and ancestor of the Hungarians, is supposed to ride down the Milky Way when the [[Székelys]] (ethnic Hungarians living in [[Transylvania]]) are threatened. Thus the Milky Way is called "The Road of the Warriors" (lit. "Road of Armies") {{lang-hu|Hadak Útja}}. The stars are sparks from their horseshoes.
===Māori=== To the [[Māori people|Māori]] the Milky Way is the [[waka (canoe)]] of [[Tama-rereti]]. The front and back of the canoe are [[Orion (constellation)|Orion]] and [[Scorpius]], while the [[Southern Cross]] and the Pointers are the anchor and rope. According to legend, when Tama-rereti took his canoe out onto a lake, he found himself far from home as night was falling. There were no stars at this time and in the darkness the [[Taniwha]] would attack and eat people. So Tama-rereti sailed his canoe along the river that emptied into the heavens (to cause rain) and scattered shiny pebbles from the lakeshore into the sky. The sky god, [[Rangi and Papa|Ranginui]], was pleased by this action and placed the canoe into the sky as well as a reminder of how the stars were made.<ref>{{cite web |title=The story of Tama Rereti and how the stars were placed in the night sky |url=http://www.carterobservatory.org/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=505&Itemid=103 |accessdate=2007-01-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060928083643/http://www.carterobservatory.org/index.php?option=content&task=view&id=505&Itemid=103 |archivedate=2006-09-28 |df= }}</ref>
===Australian Aboriginal=== {{Unreferenced section|date=July 2009}} The Kaurna Aboriginal People of the Adelaide Plains in South Australia see the band of the Milky Way as a river in the skyworld. They called it Wodliparri (wodli = hut, house, parri = river) and believe that positioned along the river are a number of dwellings. In addition, the dark patches mark the dwelling place of a dangerous creature known as a ''yura''; the Kaurna call these patches Yurakauwe, which literally means "monster water." Moreover, Aboriginal Groups from the Cape York region of Queensland see the band of light as termites that had been blown into the sky by the ancestral hero Burbuk Boon. Further south the band of stars that comprise the Milky Way are seen as thousands of flying foxes carrying away a dancer known as Purupriggie.
In addition, the Aranda who come from central Australia see the band of the Milky Way as a river or creek in the skyworld. This stellar river separates the two great camps of the Aranda and Luritja People. The stars to the east of this river represent the camps of the Aranda and the stars to the west represent Luritja encampments and some stars closer to the band represent a mixture of both.
== See also == * [[List of names for the Milky Way]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *[[Rick Riordan]], [[John Rocco]], [[Disney Publishing Worldwide|Disney Hyperion]] (2015) ''Hercules does twelve stupid things. In Percy Jackson's Greek heroes (pp. 259-329). New York, NY: Los Angeles''
==External links== * [http://www.ianridpath.com/startales/milkyway.htm Star Tales – Milky Way]

{{Infobox video game | title=OsWALD | image= | alt = | developer=[[Ivan Sølvason]] | publisher= | modes=[[Single-player]] | platforms=[[Amiga]], [[Commodore 64]] [[MS-DOS]] }} '''''OsWALD''''', also known as '''''OsWALD Of The Ice Floes''''',<ref>http://hol.abime.net/2326</ref> is a 1988 Danish computer game for [[Amiga]] and [[Commodore 64]]. The game was designed by [[Ivan Sølvason]] for use as a game controlled over a [[push-button telephone]], for [[TV 2 (Denmark)|Danish TV2]]'s Friday night prime time program [[Eleva2ren]]. The game sold well in Denmark due to the exposure in Eleva2ren.<ref name="slides">http://datamuseum.dk/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/OsWALD-og-Hugo-pr%C3%A6sentation.pdf</ref>
Sølvason later designed ''[[Hugo (franchise)|Hugo the TV Troll]]'', also for Eleva2ren and using the same push-button telephone concept. Hugo the TV Troll went on to be an international success.
==Super OsWALD== A new version of the game named '''''Super OsWALD''''', featuring two-player mode, was created for Eleva2ren in 1989.<ref name="slides" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LtktP1rqaSQ Amiga Longplay OsWALD] - World of Longplays, YouTube * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GfAHoKY3HOM Amiga Longplay Super OsWALD] - World of Longplays, YouTube * [http://datamuseum.dk/danskerne-og-datamaterne/tema-rum-2/oswald-og-hugo/ OsWald og Hugo (1988 og 1990)] - Dansk Datahistorisk Forening
[[Category:1998 video games]] [[Category:Amiga games]] [[Category:Commodore 64 games]] [[Category:DOS games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Denmark]]
{{computer-game-stub}}

{{Infobox song | name = Pagan Poetry | cover = BjörkPaganPeotry.png | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Björk]] | album = [[Vespertine]] | B-side = {{flatlist| * "Domestica" * "Batabid" * "Aurora" }} | released = 5 November 2001 | format = {{flatlist| * [[CD single|CD]] * [[DVD single|DVD]] }} | recorded = | studio = | venue = | genre = | length = {{flatlist| * 5:17 (album version) * 4:01 (radio edit) }} | label = [[One Little Indian]] | writer = Björk | producer = {{flatlist| * Björk * Marius de Vries }} | prev_title = [[Hidden Place]] | prev_year = 2001 | next_title = [[Cocoon (Björk song)|Cocoon]] | next_year = 2002 }} "'''Pagan Poetry'''" is a song recorded by Icelandic singer [[Björk]] for her fourth album, ''[[Vespertine]]''. It was released as the second single from the album on 5 November 2001, by [[One Little Indian Records]]. The single peaked at number 38 in the UK and number 15 in Canada. == Writing and recording == It was written and produced by Björk with additional production by [[Marius de Vries]] and mixed by [[Mark Stent|Mark "Spike" Stent]]. The music box adaptation, featured in the song, was done by Jack Perron and the full version was later featured as a B-side song on the "[[Cocoon (Björk song)|Cocoon]]" single. ==Critical reception== Heather Phares of [[AllMusic]] said of "Pagan Poetry" that it "shares a spacious serenity with the album's quietest moments" and included this song as a track pick.{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/vespertine-mw0000586936 |title=Vespertine – Björk |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |accessdate=24 January 2018 |last=Phares |first=Heather}} ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' said, "In 'Pagan Poetry', she deploys the implied heaven of Zeena Parkins harp and a flotilla of music boxes with an Asian-teahouse touch".{{cite journal |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/albumreviews/vespertine-20010820 |title=Vespertine |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=20 August 2001|accessdate=24 January 2018 |last=Fricke |first=David |authorlink=David Fricke}} ''[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]'' said "'Pagan Poetry' sounds like the prelude to a particularly exotic sexual interlude".{{cite web|last=Kot|first=Greg|url=http://www.blender.com/guide/reviews.aspx?id=866|title=Bjork - Vespertine|work=[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]|accessdate=24 January 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041024140049/http://www.blender.com/guide/reviews.aspx?id=866|archivedate=24 October 2004}} Saul Campbell from ''7'' magazine called the track "terrifying" and an album standout.https://web.archive.org/web/20040216073704/http://unit.bjork.com/specials/magz/pics/7mag/7-review.jpg In March 2006, on the Spanish edition of ''Rolling Stone'', "Pagan Poetry" was ranked number 38 by Spanish music professionals and experts on a list of the best songs of the 21st century.{{cite journal|title=Las 100 mejores canciones del siglo XXI|date=March 2006|journal=[[Rolling Stone|Rolling Stone España]]|issue=77|language=Spanish}} ''[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]'' placed the song at number 227 on its list of "The Top 500 Tracks of the 2000s".{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/features/lists-and-guides/7685-the-top-500-tracks-of-the-2000s-500-201/?page=2|title=The Top 500 Tracks of the 2000s: 500-201|date=17 August 2009|accessdate=24 January 2018|work=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]}} ==Music video== [[File:Bjork Pagan-Poetry 095.jpg|thumb|180px|left|Björk wearing an in-body-pierced-wedding dress designed by English fashion designer [[Alexander McQueen]] in the music video.]] The accompanying [[music video]] for "Pagan Poetry" was directed by [[Nick Knight (photographer)|Nick Knight]], who had previously photographed the cover image for her third studio album ''[[Homogenic]]'' (1997).{{cite web|url=http://unit.bjork.com/specials/gh/SUB-07/index.htm|title=Pagan Poetry|accessdate=25 January 2018|publisher=Bjork.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629004356/http://unit.bjork.com/specials/gh/SUB-07/index.htm|archivedate=29 June 2012}} The video is described as being about "a woman preparing herself for marriage and for her lover". It features highly blurry and stylized images of explicit sex from Björk's personal footage, including [[fellatio]] and [[ejaculation]], and images of large needles sewing pearls to skin.{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/house/article/top-10-bjork-music-videos|title=Top 10 Björk Music Videos|last=Cinquemani|first=Sal|date=5 July 2013|publisher=[[Slant Magazine]]|accessdate=25 January 2018}} The second half of the video features Björk in a dress designed by [[Alexander McQueen]], which covers only the lower portion of her body. The upper portion of the dress consists of pearls piercing her skin, which is shown throughout the first half.{{cite web|url=http://unit.bjork.com/specials/gh/SUB-07/making/|title=The Light of Love: The Making of the Pagan Poetry Video|last=Alien|first=Rock|date=2002|publisher=bjork.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050509084401/http://unit.bjork.com/specials/gh/SUB-07/making/|archivedate=9 May 2005}} The video ends with a shot of a [[Corset piercing]]. The video had three stages of shooting: a video shoot of piercings, a private video shoot handled by Björk, and a film shoot of Björk. The piercings video and film shoot were done in a day in June 2001 in Knight's studio in London. The sole light source was diffused sunlight shining through the ceiling windows of the second floor daylight studio. This studio gave a "northlight" look and had a rawness to it that matched the subject matter, photography director Simon Chaudoir said. Five young women who were into subculture and piercings were cast for the video. Knight directed Chaudoir to shoot the piercings by placing the Sony Mini DV camera on the women's bodies—mostly chests, arms, and shoulders—and getting as physically near as he could while maintaining a close, macro focus on a wide-angle lens. A nurse and piercing unit were on hand, but no thimble, so the bleeding most often came from cast girls' thumbs as they pushed the needles in. "It was one of the most difficult things I've ever filmed because I felt I was on the verge of throwing up. I liked to actually only watch it by the video monitor rather than with my eyes as it were because it was just too much", Chaudoir said. Björk also pierced her own ear at the shoot, but all other piercings were the cast girls'. Knight gave Björk a Sony Mini DV camera and asked her to shoot her own private scenes. {{Quote box | width = 30% | align = right | quote = "I wanted to strip her down. She's actually quite raw, womanly and sexy. There's a different side to her that doesn't come across normally in her videos. That's what I asked her to do and that's what she did. I gave her a Sony Mini DV camera and asked her to shoot her own private scenes ... She asked me to make a film about her love life, so I merely gave it back to her and said, 'Film your love life.{{'"}} | source = —Nick Knight on the video's development.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/bjork-188-1375717|title=The piercing sound of Bjork|date=19 October 2001|accessdate=25 January 2018|work=[[NME]]}} }} Tired of music videos which featured the singer looking to the camera and lip-synching throughout, Chaudoir suggested having Björk lip-synch and look into the camera only for some of the last lines. He also suggested using a track so they could move closer to her as she sings these lines or move closer before she sings them—"so it's like a reveal of her", he said. There was no script, so some improvisation made it to the final cut. Since blue-screening and [[Computer-generated_imagery|CGI]] work were not involved, Chaudoir did not use diffusion or consulted with post-production, and he arrived with only a few assistants—a gaffer, loader, grip, focus puller, and some electricians. "Basically what I was asked to do and what I thought I'd be able to do is more or less there. It would have benefited from being simplified down to a much more bold and direct visualization of what she was trying to do. I think we were too subtle in that", Knight said. The video was banned by [[MTV]] in the United States, but was eventually shown in unedited form on [[MTV2]] in a presentation of the "20 Most Controversial Music Videos".{{cite web |url=http://diffuser.fm/bjork-cocoon-banned-music-videos/|title=Bjork, ‘Cocoon’ – Banned Music Videos|last1=Robinson|first1=Joe|date=5 July 2013|website=[[Diffuser.fm]]|publisher=Townsquare Media|accessdate=3 January 2015}} The music video was placed sixth on the "20 Of The Most Controversial Music Videos Ever" list by ''NME'', which described it as "scarier than her dead swan dress or when she punched that photographer".{{cite web|last=Wright|first=Lisa|url=http://www.nme.com/list/20-of-the-most-controversial-music-videos-ever/373505#fECiYIozjt2ZqDMi.99|title=Top 10 Björk Music Videos|date=20 March 2015|work=NME|accessdate=25 January 2018}} It was also included on the list by ''Rolling Stone'', "The 15 Most NSFW Music Videos of All Time",{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/pictures/the-15-most-nsfw-music-videos-of-all-time-20110713/bjoerk-pagan-poetry-2-aa-436943|title=The 15 Most NSFW Music Videos of All Time|date=13 July 2011|work=Rolling Stone|accessdate=25 January 2018}} and was considered by ''Slant'' the sixth best music video by Björk. The dress was shown in [[Björk (exhibition)|Björk's MoMA retrospective]] in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/la-a-tour-of-the-bjrk-exhibition-at-moma-20150-008-photo.html|title=Scandalous dress|accessdate=25 January 2018|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}} It was sold as part of Kerry Taylor Auctions "Passion for Fashion" sale in London, in June 2016.{{cite web|url=https://www.the-saleroom.com/en-gb/auction-catalogues/kerrytaylor/catalogue-id-kerry-10002/lot-8da7650c-b61d-4434-b936-a60f00edb12f|title=Björk's Alexander McQueen pearl beaded 'bridal' gown, made for the Pagan Poetry' video, 2001|accessdate=25 January 2018|publisher=The Saleroom}} ==Live performances== In 2001, Björk performed "Pagan Poetry" on the ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]'' with a Greenland women's choir, harpist and electronica duo [[Matmos]].http://pitchfork.com/thepitch/764-lettermans-musical-legacy/ ==Track listing== ;CD 1 #"Pagan Poetry" (video edit) – 4:01 #"Pagan Poetry ([[Matthew Herbert]] Handshake Mix)" – 6:16 #"Aurora ([[Thomas Knak|Opiate]] Version)" – 4:06 ;CD2 #"Pagan Poetry" – 5:17 #"Domestica" – 3:25 #"Batabid" – 2:26 ;DVD #"Pagan Poetry" (video) #"Pagan Poetry ([[Matthew Herbert]] Handshake Mix)" #"Aurora ([[Thomas Knak|Opiate]] Version)" ==Charts== {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" !scope="col"|Chart (2001) !scope="col"|Peak
position |- !scope="row"|Australia ([[ARIA Charts|ARIA]]){{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150605213523/http://i.imgur.com/DkGCr8v.jpg|url=http://i.imgur.com/DkGCr8v.jpg|archivedate=5 June 2015|title=Response from ARIA re: chart inquiry, received 2015-06-05|accessdate=2015-10-09|publisher=[[Imgur]]}} |align="center"|106 |- !scope="row"|Canada ([[Canadian Singles Chart|Nielsen SoundScan]])https://books.google.com/books?id=JRIEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA70 |align="center"|15 |- {{singlechart|France|49|artist=Björk|song=Pagan Poetry|accessdate=1 October 2016|rowheader=true}} |- !scope="row"|Italy ([[Federazione Industria Musicale Italiana|FIMI]])https://books.google.com/books?id=JRIEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA70 |align="center"|20 |- !scope="row"|Portugal ([[Associação Fonográfica Portuguesa|AFP]]){{cite web|url=http://top40-charts.com/chart.php?cid=20&date=2001-11-15|title=Top40-charts.com|accessdate=24 November 2015}} |align="center"|4 |- {{singlechart|Scotland|60|date=20011117|rowheader=true|accessdate=22 November 2018}} |- {{singlechart|Spain|6|artist=Björk|song=Pagan Poetry|accessdate=1 October 2016|rowheader=true}} |- {{singlechart|UK|38|date=20011117|rowheader=true|accessdate=1 October 2016|refname="uk"}} |- {{singlechart|UKindie|5|date=20011117|rowheader=true|accessdate=22 November 2018}} |} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120629004356/http://unit.bjork.com/specials/gh/SUB-07/index.htm Pagan Poetry webpage] * [http://showstudio.com/project/pagan_poetry/film Pagan Poetry - uncensored video] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120930183924/http://unit.bjork.com/specials/gh/SUB-07/making/ The Light of Love - The making of the Pagan Poetry video] * [http://www.showstudio.com/projects/031/031_start.html SHOWstudio - Pagan Poetry mini-site by the video creators] * [http://www.nme.com/news/bjork/9692 The Piercing Sound of Björk: Nudity and piercing shows her as "raw, womanly and sexy"...], ''[[NME]]'' Article on the video {{Björk songs}} [[Category:2001 singles]] [[Category:Björk songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Björk]] [[Category:2001 songs]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Björk]] [[Category:Songs about sexuality]] [[Category:Music video controversies]]
